hits.name: Mount Tammany: Red Dot and Blue Dot Loop Trail
hits.description:
Mount Tammany is one of the most popular hikes in New Jersey, and for good reason! The trail offers sweeping views of the Delaware Water Gap, without too much of a challenge. The trailhead is also easily accessed, right off of Interstate 80.

Although there are several large parking areas, they do fill up quickly on warm weekends. It’s best to arrive early to secure a spot. Wherever you end up parking, it will be a short walk to the trailhead at the Dunfield Creek Natural Area Trailhead.

This loop can be done in either direction, but most people choose the counter-clockwise route mapped on this page. There is a section along the Red Dot Trail that requires scrambling up a steep rocky face. This scramble is best done going up hill, so counter-clockwise up the Red Dot Trail and then down the Blue Dot Trail (Pahaquarry Trail).

There are views the whole way up the Red Dot Trail. After making it to the summit, continue westward on the Blue Dot Trail. This trail has a more gradual decline, eventually passing a swimming hole with some small waterfalls. 

You’ll take a left and briefly hike along Dunnfield Creek on the Appalachian Trail. After a short walk you’ll be back at the parking area.

If you’re looking for something shorter, you can forego Mount Tammany and simply walk along Dunnfield Creek to the swimming hole instead.

hits.name: White Shore and Long Path Loop Trail
hits.description:
This is a difficult, sometimes rugged, hike with outstanding views. There are also waterfalls and ruins along the way.

White Shore and Long Path Loop begins in the parking area at the State Line Lookout. Start hiking on the trail with a sign that reads "Ski Trails." From there, you will see blue blazes to start along the Long Loop.

The first part going north from the Palisades Interstate Park Visitor Center and Cafe head down the cliff with moderate exertion and you get to a beautiful waterfall emptying into the Hudson. At this point, if you want an easier hike, you can turn around and go back up. If you continue the loop and head south along the Hudson, it gets harder with rockier sections of the trail. The most difficult part of the hike is a section called the Giant Stairs. This is a challenging trail but many hikers claim that the views are certainly worth the effort!

hits.name: Stairway to Heaven Trail
hits.description:
There is a parking lot at the start of the trail off of Vernon Warwick Road at the Appalachian Boardwalk Entrance. The route begins as a steep climb up to the top of Wawayanda Mountain on the Appalachian Trail. Along the way up there are many large boulders that are great for bouldering. Once on top, you will get a great view of the Vernon Valley, Pochuck Mountain, the Kittatinny's, Catskills, and the Black Dirt region.

The trail then traverses the top of Wawayanda Mountain to another lookout. This is when you will start your bushwhacking along the old Appalachian trail route. It is more like a bushwhack because you may have difficulties finding the trail most of the way as you go down the mountain.  While descending you will pass a waterfall and some nice cascades. Be careful on this section as there are many unstable rocks in the area. As you go right onto the unmarked path, follow along the mountain base back to the Appalachian Trail.

hits.name: Buttermilk Falls and Crater Lake Loop Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description:
This loop trail has a little of everything and showcases what the Delaware Water Gap national recreation area has to offer: waterfalls, ravines, valley walking, steep climbs, ridge walking, views and even a bushwhack.

Buttermilk Falls trail is short and sweet and leads to one of the easier waterfalls in New Jersey to see as it lies so close to the road. At the junction with Woods Road look for the Appalachian Trail which branches to the left and is blue blazed. You will follow the AT to Crater Lake Trail, and after walking a loop around Crater Lake you will skirt Hemlock Pond before rejoining Woods Road back to the parking lot.

hits.name: Hemlock Falls Trail via Lenape (Yellow) Trail, Rahway Trail (White) and River Trail
hits.description: Beautiful hike with some rough terrain. A good amount of inclines. Rocky trails. Really nice stretch along a ridge. Great hike to a small waterfall.

hits.name: Schooley's Mountain Boulder Gorge Loop Trail
Stairway to Heaven and Pochuck Valley via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
This hike starts out at the AT crossing on Route 517 the Pochuck Valley and starts out flat for about 2.5 miles on boardwalks, a suspension bridge, and a cow pasture. It then crosses Rt. 94 and enters the "stairway to heaven" - a steep set of switchbacks over rocky terrain that wind their way up.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces alongside McAfee Glenwood Road at the northwest end of the trail. There is paved streetside parking enough for about 25 - 30 vehicles. The trail surface is a wooden boardwalk and bridge (with edge barriers and partial railings), packed gravel, natural (grass, rock, dirt), and typically 2 to 5 feet wide. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.9 miles heading southeast along the boardwalk and suspension bridge. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for steep to very steep (over 8%) uphill and downhill sections after about 0.9 miles when going southeast. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas.

hits.name: MacEvoy, Castle, and Cannonball Trail Loop
hits.description: Take the blue-blazed McEvoy Trail from the parking lot. The trail climbs to Ramapo Lake where it joins a paved park road as it skirts the lake then turns north. The trail leaves the road at a sharp bend. Stay on road for about 50 yards and take the white-blazed Castle Point Trail and begin a short, steep climb. At the top are some interesting ruins and outstanding views. Continue on the trail along the ridge. The trail then descends, crosses a stream, and turns uphill where it joins another park road and ends at Skyline Drive. Cross Skyline and take the red-blazed Cannonball Trail. Then a quick right onto the yellow-blazed Hoeferlin Trail. Follow the trail until it reaches Skyline Dr again and catch the white-blazed Todd Trail by the  Camp Tamarack sign.  The Todd turns west into the woods and eventually joins a gravel camp road for a short distance,  then turns south and reaches another outstanding overlook. Continue on Todd, across Skyline again and back to McEvoy. Take a left on MacEvoy to return to the car.

hits.name: Mount Tammany via Red Dot Trail
hits.description:
Hikers visiting the top of Mount Tammany can take a variety of routes. The route shown on this page follows the Red Dot Trail up a steep and rocky trail to the summit. This route then has the hiker turn around come back down the Red Dot Trail.

Many hikers choose to continue past the summit onto the Blue Dot Trail eventually returning to the parking lot. You could also take the Blue Dot Trail up and back - which is easier than the Red Dot Trail. Parking is limited (~150 spots) and area roads. Please make arrangements to factor in the time to locate parking if attempting a dusk hike on weekends.

hits.name: Chikahoki Falls via Highlands, Post Brook, and Carris Hill Trail
Devil's Half-Acre, Ridge, and Tributary Trail Loop
hits.description:
Gentle climb to top of Sourland Mountain. Beautiful views of woodlands and two large boulder fields. Follow white square blazes until you reach Roaring Brook Trail (red circle blazes).  Roaring Brook Trail is 2.1 miles before it rejoins the Ridge Trail and returns to the trailhead at the parking lot.

The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species.

The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: Sunfish Pond via AT and Dunnfield Creek Trail Loop
hits.description: This hike is a moderate climb to Sunfish Pond, following the Appalachian Trail (white) heading north. The trail is well maintained and well used by day hikers and overnighters alike. The hike has a few strenuous climbs, but mostly evenly graded climbs with a few level areas in between. Follow the Dunnfield Hollow Trail down from Sunfish Pond to make it a loop. This trail does have some rather steep sections. The Dunnfield Creek Trail is blazed light green.

hits.name: Vista Loop Trail
hits.description:
Yellow blazes mark this trail. From the parking area, follow the dirt trail to the bridge that crosses the Ramapo River and continue straight with the Scarlet Oak Pond on the right. Immediately once past the end of the pond, take the path to the right that continues to hug the pond and further down this path on the left is a wooden footbridge that begins the ascent for this trail. The ascent will climb at moderately steep grade to start and become more level further along the trail. Towards the end, the trail will eventually lead to a large downhill rock which descends down towards the MacMillan Reservoir where it then bears left and eventually goes across the dam. Following the dam, it then continues down a partially paved and gravel portion of the trail where it then bears right. Before a small bridge, a tree with a single yellow blaze will be off to the right, continuing the trail down past a water fall and back to the starting point.
 
Points of Interest:
  - Hawk Rock Overlook (At the top of the initial ascent of the trail, a nice overlook view of the Ramapo Valley area including Ramapo College campus and on a clear day, the New York City skyline in the distance).
 
  - Cactus Ledge (A bit further along the trail from and above Hawk Rock Overlook, features the only native growing cactus in the United States east of the Rocky Mountains).
 
  - Ridge Overlook (Provides a higher view than the Hawk Rock Overlook and a move visible view of the valley and New York City skyline).

hits.name: Cheesequake Green Trail
hits.description: There's a $5 entrance fee on weekdays between Memorial Day and Labor Day, and a $10 entrance fee on weekends and holidays between Memorial Day and Labor Day.

hits.name: Doctor's Creek and Old Forge Trail
Highlands, Posts Brook, Carris Hill and Wyanokie Loop
hits.description:
Take blue trail from the parking lot and stay on the blue trail at the fork. Continue onto the white trail and stay on it until the yellow trail. Take it up the hill and at the end turn right onto the blue trail, then turn left onto the red/white trail (or turn right to see Wyanokie High Point), continue to the orange trail, then right on the yellow trail, then take the blue/green trail until the first fork to the path to the parking lot.

Parking at the Otter Hole lot fills up quickly. Overflow parking can be found about a half a mile away on the same road.

hits.name: Long Loop via Peanut Leap Cascade, Giant Stairs and Closter Dock
hits.description:
This trail is recommended for people who love stairs and rock scrambling and is not for beginners. It is rated moderate but can definitely be hard if you are not used to scrambling. 

Park in the lot by the State Line Cafe (aka the Lookout Inn), off the Palisades Parkway, Alpine, NJ. The Long Path trail head (green rectangular blazes) is just north of the Cafe. Going clockwise, follow this for about 1.1 miles until you hit the Shore trail marked by white rectangular blazes. Descending past Peanut Leap Cascade, you'll then head South and at the hike's 1.9 mile point, you'll start the Giant Stairs rock scramble which lasts for just over a mile. (It's challenging.) After that, it's smooth sailing as you keep the Hudson to your left, still on the Shore trail, all the way down to Closter Dock, Alpine Landing, which is the 6.1 mile mark. Then, retracing your steps a little way, at the 6.4 mile point, you'll join the Closter Dock trail (switchbacking Westwards) which will reconnect you to the Long Path trail, going North again. Then, it's about 3.4 miles back to the Cafe.

hits.name: Hacklebarney Loop Trail
hits.description:
Waterfall. Wild Trout Streams, Black River, Hemlock forest, Deep Ravines

This loop hike is great if you are looking to get out for the day but relax more than hike.  The hike will take you down into the Blackriver as well as along Trout and Rhinehart Brook, Hemlock Ravines and mature hardwood forests.  The trails are wide and have gravel put down.  If you want that challenge there are a few trails along the Black River that are more like hiking trails, narrow and rocky.  This hike will take you through both trail types.  Along the trails you will pass many benches and picnic areas.  There are also old water fountains along the way that where built by the Civilian Conservation Cor, during the depression.  They no longer work though.  The trails are all unmarked but will be getting marked in the next year.  The best time to hike the area is during the week when you will only encounter  fly fisherman.  Weekends tend to get crowded.

hits.name: Surprise Lake Loop
hits.description: Great hike with some scrambling, rocky areas, and awesome views of Greenwood Lake!

hits.name: Shore Trail and Long Trail Loop from Alpine Picnic Area
Bearfort Ridge and Surprise Lake Loop
hits.description: From parking at Warwick Turnpike follow the road for about 0.2 miles and then turn onto the green-blazed Bearfort Ridge Loop trail. Meet the yellow-blazed Ernest Walter trail and follow this to the blue-blazed State Line Trail. From there, continue on to the white-blazed Appalachian Trail, and then turn back onto the yellow-blazed Ernest Walter trail. You'll meet back up with the green-blazed Bearfort Ridge loop, and will follow this back to parking at Warwick Turnpike.

hits.name: Hewitt-Butler, Highlands, Roomy Mine and Mine Trail
Allaire Orange Trail
hits.description:
Pleasant, easy walk through some scenic woods. This is mostly a mountain biking route. 

This entire hike follows the Orange Trail.  Catch it beyond the kiosk at the west end of the parking lot and stay right. You need to play very close attention, as the trail is not blazed well in places and there are numerous unmarked trails in the area. The blazes actually look red much of the time. The Orange Trail soon joins with the White Trail and together they pass a golf course on the right. White Trail leaves to left. Continue northwest on Orange. It reaches a stream and turns southwest, following the stream for a while. It joins the Blue Trail, then leaves it as the Orange Trail turns south.  The Orange joins the Blue Trail again for a short distance, but continues southeast while the Blue Trail leave to the left. The trail then skirts a gravel pit and you're back in the parking lot shortly afterward.

hits.name: Peaceful Partners Trail and Long Path Loop
hits.description:
The Peaceful Partners Trail (blue) is relatively wide. The others are a little tighter. Markings are a bit sparse in parts.

This area experiences partial closures from flooding and downed trees seasonally.

Easy trails through the bogs. Relatively easy to navigate. If the main trailheads are packed there are several other areas where you can park and enter.

Trail Map: https://blackrun.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/BlackRunMapJune2017.pdf

hits.name: Blackwells, Creek, and Cedar Trail Loop
Mount Tammany and Sunfish Pond Loop
hits.description: This route traverses the Red Dot, Blue Dot, Dunnfield Creek (light green), and Appalachian (white) Trails. Some sections are very steep and rocky.

hits.name: Ted Stiles Preserve at Baldpate Mountain
hits.area_name: Ted Stiles Preserve at Baldplate Mountain
hits.description:
The Ted Stiles Preserve stretches across almost 1,800 acres of a ridge running roughly east-west, between Fiddlers Creek Road to the south and Pleasant Valley Road to the north.

Baldpate Mountain offers some of the most extensive and rugged walking in Mercer County.  Some old logging roads and some specially built trails lace the southern and northern flanks of the ridge, and a 2-mile trail runs along its spine. There are great views of the Delaware River to the south, historic farmland to the north, and on clear days the Philadelphia skyline to the southwest. Ruins of a 19th century settlement and scattered farms can be found on or near some of the Baldpate trails. Most trails involve climbing or descending. Some sections of trail may be wet and muddy. Some trails include steep stone steps, which require a moderate degree of caution. None of the trails are paved.

hits.name: Openwood, River, Lenape, and Overlook Trails Loop
Garret Mountain Yellow and White Loop Trail
Rocky Point Loop Trail
hits.description: Hartshorne Woods County Park has 16 miles of hiking and mountain biking trails, several old military bunkers and a small beach with a fishing pier. The Park is split into three sections from west to east: The Buttermilk Valley Section, the Monmouth Hills Section and the Rocky Point Section.

hits.name: White Trail, East Shore Drive, and Foxcroft Road Loop
Sunfish Pond via Appalachian Trail
hits.description: This trail follows white blazes to Sunfish Pond, and is well maintained but steep and rocky. There are bear boxes and toilets on the way.

hits.name: Raccoon Ridge via Appalachian, Kaiser, and Coppermine Trails Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Eagle Rock Red Trail Loop
hits.description: Eagle Rock Reservation is located on the borders of West Orange, Verona, and Montclair, New Jersey. The Reservation enjoys an unrivaled view of the New York City skyline from the Essex County 911 Memorial. From here you can view the George Washington Bridge to the Verrazano Narrows Bridge. For more information visit: http://www.eaglerockreservation.org/

hits.name: Blueberry Hill Loop
Turkey Mountain via Red and Yellow Trail
hits.description:
Hike over varied terrain to some views and seasonal waterfall Catch the blue blazed Butler-Montville Trail in the northeast corner of the parking lot. The trail soon begins to climb the "100 Steps" section, reaching the top where there are views to the east and west. Bear left (north) on the Red Trail, skirt the summit of Turkey Mtn (a view is just beyond the summit on a large rock outcrop), then bear left (north) on the Yellow Trail. It descends slowly, reaching a road where it crosses a stream and heads back into the woods. It parallels a road for a bit, turns west and crosses a bridge where there is a seasonal waterfall to the right. It passes under power lines, goes through a wet, rocky area, then levels out. From here its a flat, easy walk back to your car.

Alternately, from the bridge/waterfall, catch the green trail going west. It climbs gently, passes stone ruins then reaches an outstanding view of Lake Valhalla. At the end of the green trail bear left on the blue trail and right on the yellow and back to your car.

hits.name: Wyanokie High Point via Highlands and Wyanokie Crest Trail
hits.description: Users have reported there is not much cell service on trail, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful for navigating.

hits.name: Creek, Twisty, and Blackwells Trail Loop
hits.description: Curvy trail with beautiful scenery along a gorgeous stream

hits.name: Batsto Lake Trail
hits.description: This loop is a combination of sandy paths, bog bridges, and pine needle-covered trails.

hits.name: Merrill Creek Reservoir Perimeter Trail
hits.description:
For up to date park information please see the park page here: https://merrillcreek.com/

This is a fantastic hike for someone looking for an easy well-defined loop trail. Plenty of access to water throughout. Trail is a bit overgrown. No bikes allowed.

hits.name: High Mountain Lookout Point and Waterfall Loop
hits.description: A good mix of wide trails and climbing with overlook. Not all trails are blazed, but it’s a nice view from the top. Follow the red trail to the yellow and back to the red.

hits.name: Hartshorne Woods: Grand Tour Trail
hits.description: Hartshorne Woods County Park has 16 miles of hiking and mountain biking trails, several old military bunkers and a small beach with a fishing pier. The Park is split into three sections from west to east: The Buttermilk Valley Section, the Monmouth Hills Section and the Rocky Point Section.

hits.name: Pyramid Mountain, Tripod Rock, Bear Rock, Whale Head Rock
hits.area_name: Pyramid Mountain County Natural Historic Area

hits.name: Lake Surprise Loop via W. R Tracy Drive
hits.description: Watchung Reservation is the largest nature reserve in Union County, New Jersey and consists of the upper valley of Blue Brook between First and Second Watchung Mountains. For more information visit: http://ucnj.org/parks-recreation/paths-trails-greenways/watchung-reservation/

hits.name: Worthington Blue Trail
hits.description: This trail ends at the Mount Tammany Lookout. It can be combined with the Red Dot Trail to make a loop back to the parking area.

hits.name: Long Path and Shore Trail: Out and Back
Roaring Rocks Trail via Devil's Half-Acre and Tributary Trail
hits.description: The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: MacMillan Reservoir Loop Trail
hits.description:
From the parking lot, follow the gravel and dirt trail to the bridge that crosses the Ramapo River and continue straight until reaching a more heavily graveled and partially paved area just past the Scarlet Oak Pond which begins the ascent up to the reservoir. 

Upon reaching the reservoir, follow the pink blazes around this loop which hugs the reservoir.

hits.name: Rancocas State Park Northern Loop
hits.description: There are an abundance of trails to choose from within this outer loop that explore a variety of ecosystems. Be aware that bugs can be plentiful throughout the spring and summer.

hits.name: Mills Reservation Trail
hits.description: No bikes allowed on this trail.

hits.name: Sandy Hook Multi-Use Trail
hits.description:
This is a well-maintained, paved biking and walking path along the coast with beach access. Fort Hancock, Sandy Hook Lighthouse and gun batteries are points of interest.

Accessibility: There are 14 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Hartshorne Drive at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. There are 16 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Gunnison Road at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 8 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along all of the trail which reduces the width. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. According to the park website, this multi-use trail is ADA-compliant. 

There is a wheelchair-accessible restroom at Guardian Park and all six beach centers have wheelchair-accessible bathrooms. Beach wheelchairs are available for loan - call ahead to the Visitor Center for more information (732-872-5970). The beach concession stands are wheelchair-accessible. The Visitor Center and Lighthouse Keeper's Quarters and Barn are also wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Historic Smithville County Park Trail
hits.description:
This route contains the red, green, blue, yellow, and even the orange trail in Smithville Park. There are paved areas and more natural areas to explore.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of East Railroad Avenue at the southeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, boardwalk with railings, packed gravel, or a natural surface. It is typically 3 to 5 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail is the first about 0.8 miles when going clockwise. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade in the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Ramapo Lake Brook Loop
hits.description: Please be mindful and considerate when hiking this trail as parts of it are on private property.

hits.name: Rancocas Creekside and Red Fox Loop
Loantaka Brook Reservation Trail
hits.description:
An easy paved path between Loantaka Way and South Street. Great for a Sunday afternoon walk through the woods.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of South Street at the northwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the northwest end of the trail.

hits.name: Ramapo Ramble Trail
hits.description: Easy trail over varied terrain, waterfalls, stone ruins. Short bushwack to views

hits.name: Cedar, River's Edge, Hidden Creek and Pine Hills Loop
hits.description: This is a great place with something for everyone. You can get lost sometimes as the markings aren't abundant, but it certainly gives an adventure!

hits.name: Red, Yellow and White Loop
hits.description: Hacklebarney State Park hike w Ali. Good water access. Waterfalls. Climbing. Chairs for picnicking.

hits.name: Hemlock Falls via Lenape (Yellow) Trail, Summit Trail, Swampy Trail, and Crest Trail
Lewis Morris Green and Yellow Loop
hits.description: As of April 2021, trails within Lewis Morris Park have been reblazed with different colors. Please follow the AllTrails route and consult Lewis Morris Park website for more information- https://www.morrisparks.net/assets/images/PDFs/Park_Maps/LMmap-REBLAZE.pdf.

hits.name: Henry Hudson Drive
hits.description: There are several route options from the trailhead on this page. You can walk along the Henry Hudson Drive, which is a paved road open to vehicular traffic, normally used by cyclists. Another option is the Shore Trail, which hugs the riverbanks and is used for walking. The final option is the Long Path, which is a walking trail along the cliffs overlooking the river. You may also choose to make a loop out of these trails.

hits.name: Watchung White, Purple and Yellow Trail Loop
hits.description: Watchung Reservation is the largest nature reserve in Union County, New Jersey and consists of the upper valley of Blue Brook between First and Second Watchung Mountains. For more information visit: http://ucnj.org/parks-recreation/paths-trails-greenways/watchung-reservation/

hits.name: Maurice River Bluffs Trail
hits.description:
The trail system features a 35-foot long bridge, steps and rails throughout the steeper parts that make the trails accessible to all levels of hikers, multiple benches and picnic tables, and a bird blind overlooking the river. This enclosure allows visitors a “bird’s eye view” of various waterfowl and eagles in their natural habitat without disturbing them. Visitors to the preserve can also take advantage of the visitor kiosk, stocked with interpretive information and large trail maps. All enhancements were made by staff and volunteers entirely with recycled materials.

As one of New Jersey’s most visited preserves, the Maurice River Bluffs provides many opportunities for outdoor recreation, including five established trails. The nature preserve is also home to a floating dock and offers an unobstructed view of two bald eagle nests, as well as many benches and picnic tables which provide scenic spots for observation and relaxation.

hits.name: Long Path: GW Bridge to Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory
hits.description: It is possible to do this as a loop, hiking back on the Bike Path (White Trail) along the river side. Please read more information here on how to complete a loop: https://www.nynjtc.org/hike/long-pathbike-path-loop-rockland-lake-state-park#dialog-hike-description

hits.name: Columbia Trail: High Bridge to Bartley
hits.area_name: Ken Lockwood Gorge Wildlife Management Area
hits.description:
This trail parallels the South Branch Raritan River along an old rail bed. The trail is named for the Columbia Gas Company which built the pipeline underneath the entire length of the trail.

Short portions of this route are along the roadway shared with motor vehicles. Wearing a helmet, bright clothing, and using lights or flags is always recommended for personal safety. 

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Main Street in High Bridge at the southwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, crushed gravel, or bridge (with railings), and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) uphill sections at about 1.0, 2.0, and 3.0 miles when going northbound. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the moderately steep sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved sections. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Washington Valley White, Blue and Orange Trail
hits.description:
Users report that parking is very limited here so it is recommended to come early. The route can be hard to follow, especially when muddy, so bringing the app or downloaded map is recommended.

Accessibility: There are 9 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Chimney Rock Park at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or a natural surface (dirt, rocks, roots, mud). It is typically at least 3 feet wide.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved portion in the 0.3 miles in Chimney Rock Park. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.9, 1.9-2.0, 2.3-2.4, 2.8, 3.1-3.5, 4.1-4.3, and 4.5-5.5 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade. The most accessible portion of the trail is the Chimney Rock Loop trail: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-jersey/chimney-rock-loop

hits.name: Franklin Parker Preserve
hits.description: Beautiful Pine Barrens trail through old cranberry bogs and blueberry fields. Follow the red trail from the Chatsworth entrance. Lots of wild and semi wild blueberries. Also a short tower which allows one to oversee the cranberry bogs, and in the middle of the woods two huge Adirondack chairs.

hits.name: Windbeam Mountain Overlook Trail
hits.description: This is a pleasant, short hike to some outstanding viewpoints to the east, southwest, west and northeast. Its a great place for a picnic lunch. Starting at parking on Stonetown Rd, follow the road south for a short distance to the blue blazed Highlands Trail (just before junction with Westbrook Rd). Turn left (east) into the woods and begin a gradual climb up the south slope of Windbeam Mountain.  You will see a few limited viewpoints along the way. The trail levels out, then after a short downhill section it joins the red & white blazed Stonetown Circular Trail. Together they climb to the top of Windbeam Mountain. Reaching the top you will come to several outstanding viewpoints, the best of which comes after a short descent into a shallow ravine and climb up the other side. From here, retrace your steps to the junction of the Highlands and  Stonetown Circular Trail and return via the Stonetown Circular.

hits.name: Scarlet Oak Pond to MacMilan Reservoir
Otter Hole, Wyanokie Crest and Circular Trail
Hewitt-Butler, Highlands and Mine Trail
hits.description: Park at New Weis Center. Follow the green trail until the second trailhead (marked with a second big display board and map). Follow the blue trail to the top. There is a larger rock balanced precariously at the summit. Continue to follow the blue tail down the other side until it meets the red trail. Follow the read trail markers until you meet the yellow path on the left. Follow the yellow path the rest of the way until it joins up with the blue path you walked at the beginning. Follow the green path back to the car.

hits.name: Point Mountain Peak to River Trail
hits.description: Steep up and gradual decent down to Musconetcong River. Beautiful vista valley views from top of Point Mountain.

hits.name: Mercer County Park (East and West) Trails
Wawayanda Lake Loop
hits.description: This loop follows the orange-blazed Wawayanda Lake loop trail to circle the lake and return to the parking areas.

hits.name: Devils Half-Acre Trail
hits.description: The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: Lucy Overlook via Blue and White Trail Loop
Cushetunk Trail
hits.description:
Terrain: There's considerable elevation gain all over the trail with lots of ups and downs so make sure you are ready for it. Sometimes it gets rocky.

Shade: You will be under the trees 95% of the time.

Scenic View: Round valley reservoir is one of the most breathtaking reservoirs in NJ. Beautiful scenic route and consider taking swimming clothes


Campsites: Lots of dispersed campsites and picnic areas around the lake.

hits.name: NW Loop and Ridge Trail via Summit Trail
hits.area_name: Ted Stiles Preserve at Baldplate Mountain

hits.name: Hewitt-Butler Trail
hits.description:
Users recommend using the offline map to get oriented as there are a few turns that are not well marked. 

This trail is a great workout and has beautiful views all along the hike. It's rocky for the most part and has steep climbs and descents but worth it because the views at the outlook are spectacular. It's rated moderate because it’s easy in some spots and more challenging in others.

hits.name: Ramapo Park Lake Loop
hits.description: The trail is not well marked in spots, downloading the map ahead of time is recommended to help with navigation.

hits.name: Musconetcong Gorge
hits.description: Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

hits.name: Jefferson Lake and Sunset Branch Loop
hits.description:
This is a loop trail on several trails in the Allamuchy Mtn State Park (Sussex Branch Trail, the Highlands trail (Blue blazes) and the the Jefferson Lake Bike path).

The terrain is a variety of flat, former rail bed or some pavement, as well as rocky, up and down trail in the woods.  The trails are well blazed as well as well used.

hits.name: The Tourne via Red and Decamp Trail Loop
hits.description:
The Tourne Loop is a great local trail. It’s short enough for a quick afternoon hike, with a well trod gravel trail that is suitable for trail runners and new hikers. That being said, there is still enough of an elevation gain to make this slightly more challenging than a typical walk in the park. 

As users come into the park turn right for a long gradual climb, turn left for a short but more steep climb. Highlights include great views to the east and south, including of the NYC skyline, as well as a very peaceful wildflower trail, with many local flora labeled and protected from deer and other animals by a high fence. Users report that this is a neat local treasure.

hits.name: Middlesex Greenway
hits.description:
The Middlesex Greenway, once part of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, is a popular 3.5-mile paved path. This is a well-designed trail and a pretty ride. There are eight interpretive signs along the trail.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Middlesex Avenue at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete (with edge barriers at bridges) and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There is a wheelchair-accessible bathroom at the west end of the trail.

hits.name: Normanook Tower via Appalachian Trail Loop
hits.description:
The loop starts out on the Appalachian Trail and then takes you onto Sunrise Mountain Road. Walk Sunrise Mountain Road a short distance to the Coursen Trail. Once on the Coursen Trail, pass through a damp and cool forest consisting of Hemlock, Mount Laurel, Rhododendrons, and several streams. 

The forest then turns into a hardwood forest with a swamp and a view of the Kittatinny Ridge. From the Coursen Trail, you will then get on the Tower Trail. Go through a stand of spruce trees, cross a stream, and start your rocky climb to the top of the Kittatinny Ridge and Culvers fire Tower. You will be rewarded with some great views of the Poconos and Delaware River Valley. From the top of the ridge, take the Appalachian Trail south along the ridge for a view through the tree.

hits.name: Yellow Trail to Pyramid Mountain
hits.area_name: Pyramid Mountain County Natural Historic Area
hits.description: This trail has some steep sections and can be slippery but is well-marked and has nice views.

hits.name: Cape May Point Trail
hits.description:
This loop is a combination of the Duck and Plover trails.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Light House Avenue at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is a wooden boardwalk with edge barriers, gravel, or a natural surface (dirt, sand). It is typically at least 4 feet wide.

The most accessible portion of the trail is boardwalk portion in the first about 0.6 when going clockwise. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type after about 0.6 miles when going clockwise

hits.name: Sunfish Pond via Red Dot, Tammany Fire Road, Turquoise, and Dunnfield Creek Trails
Tall Pines
hits.description:
Tall Pines is the only state park in Gloucester County, NJ, and consists of 110 acres of open land, woods, ponds, streams, and wetlands on a former golf course that is located in Mantua and Deptford Townships.

It is a well-used park and because most of the trails are paved, there are a lot of small kids and families that enjoy this park.  On the other side of Mantua Creek from the parking lot, the park is a bit hillier and woodier.  The paths are also a little more deteriorated and grown over, but this side of the park has great views.  

While the are only two marked paths (the 2.37 mile Green Trail that is on both sides of the creek and the 0.5 mile Red Trail on the parking lot side of the creek), there are over four miles of former cart paths that you are permitted to use in the park.  In some areas, different cart paths are linked by mowed grass trails to make better loops.

hits.name: MacEvoy Trail to East Shore Drive to Foxcroft Road to Castle Point Trail
Maple Flats, Tributary, and Devil's Half-Acre Trail Loop
hits.description: The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: Watchung Yellow, Purple and White Loop
Round Valley Blue Trail and Pine Trail Loop
Eagle Rock Yellow and Red Trail Loop
hits.description: Eagle Rock Reservation is located on the borders of West Orange, Verona, and Montclair, New Jersey. The Reservation enjoys an unrivaled view of the New York City skyline from the Essex County 911 Memorial. From here you can view the George Washington Bridge to the Verrazano Narrows Bridge. For more information visit: http://www.eaglerockreservation.org/

hits.name: Batona Trail
hits.description: This pink-blazed trail through the Jersey Pines can be accessed from several points, and many miles of sand roads can be used to create loop hikes. There are back country campsites (permit required) in Wharton State Forest at Buttonwood Hill, Lower Forge and Batona Camp, as well as campgrounds in Bass River State Forest at Lake Absegami just off Stage Road, and in Brendan T. Byrne State Forest at Brendan T. Byrne Camp just off Rt. 72. The trail is mostly level, passing through Pine/ Oak forest and Atlantic White Cedar swamps, crossing small streams, and meeting the Batsto River at a few spots, with a not-very high point at Apple Pie Hill, 205 feet above sea level.

hits.name: Devils Half-Acre, Tributary, and Maple Flats Trail Loop
hits.description: The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: Apshawa Preserve: Green Loop
hits.description:
Users have reported that the parking area for this trail is very small, and often fills up early on weekends. No parking is allowed in the adjacent neighborhood.

This route has beautiful views: mountain overlook, waterfall, and lake.

hits.name: Rutgers Ecological Preserve Green and Orange Loop
Liberty State Park and New York Bay
hits.description:
Located on Upper New York Bay, opposite Liberty Island and Ellis Island.  It has wonderful views of Manhattan and the Hudson River.  The park covers 1,212 acres, including a 36 acre nature preserve.  There are many fields, bike paths and walkways, including Liberty Walkway along the bay/river.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Freedom Way at the southwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with partial edge barriers and railings). It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There is a wheelchair-accessible bathroom at the southwest end of the trail.

hits.name: Goat Hill Overlook
hits.description: This is a nice and easy hike with amazing views.

hits.name: Sunset, Rahway, River, Balls Bluff and Lenape Loop
hits.description: Park at the Locust Grove lot (near Millburn Library). From there, take the Sunset trail (for 0.6 miles), then join the white blazed Rahway trail (for 0.2 miles), then join the River trail (for 1.3 miles). At that point, your way will curve east to south east on the Balls Bluff trail (for 0.3 of a mile). At just over the half way mark, join the yellow blazed Lenape trail and continue on for another 1.9 miles until you reach Sunset again. Take a right, then a quick left, and you'll be back to the lot.

hits.name: Six Mile Run Reservoir Red and Orange Trails
hits.description: Often to referred to as Six Mile Run Reservoir site, this area strangely has no reservoir to be seen. There are, however, serene trails for walking, running, and mountain biking. You will pass through forest and along streams. This is a very popular portion of the park, running between Lincoln Highway and South Middlebush Road. You can cross South Middlebush to continue exploring the park.

hits.name: Terrace Pond West Loop
hits.description: Follow the Yellow blazes from Clinton Road to Terrace Pond to make a loop. Existing trails and woods roads create a loop from Clinton Road that offers diverse forests and swamp views while leading you to Terrace Pond.

hits.name: Otter Hole, Wyanokie Crest, Highlands and Hewitt-Butler Trail
hits.description: Many intersections/trail junctions are not well marked, downloading the map ahead of time to help navigate is helpful.

hits.name: Rifle Camp Park - Yellow Loop
hits.description: Rifle Camp Park offers diverse opportunities to walk trails and recreate outdoors.

hits.name: Cushetunk Mountain White and Blue Trail
hits.description: This trail starts with a tough directly uphill, no recommendable for beginners or children. It is overgrowth and rocky at the summit, very well marked though.

hits.name: NW Loop Trail via Strawberry Hill Summit
hits.area_name: Ted Stiles Preserve at Baldplate Mountain

hits.name: Lenape Trail: South Mountain Reservation Section
hits.description: Park at Glen Avenue lot (Locust Grove) in Millburn and start by taking the right-hand trail. Follow the yellow blazes all the way through to Mayapple Hill in West Orange. (If you like, you can take a short loop detour to see Hemlock Falls on the way.) Once at Mayapple Hill, turn around and retrace your steps.

hits.name: Orange Reservoir Loop
hits.description:
A beautiful, gentle, paved trail around a lake. Some wildlife to be observed, easy for all ages. 

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Cherry Lane at the northwest end of the trail. Most of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) . This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Ramapo Schuber and Ridge Loop Trail
hits.description:
Offline map is recommended. Users have reported that the trails are not marked well.

Begin at the main entrance and take the Halifax Trail around Scarlet Oak Pond. Here the park has an urban feel, paved roads and many dog walkers & joggers. The trail enters the woods, becomes more rugged & begins to climb towards Hawk Rock. Here you can clearly see all the way to NYC. The Halifax Trail leads down to Havemeyer Rd, and old mine rd, and meets a pipe line road. Follow this up over Drag Hill to the Cannonball Trail. 

This area became park property in the 70's & many houses & foundations can be found intact around Bear Swamp Lake. The Cannonball Trail leads you through the BSA's Camp Yaw Paw and to the Yellow trail. Climb and cross the pipeline road again to wonderful views of the Ramapo Valley below. Descend to meet the Bear Swamp Creek.

hits.name: River, Overlook and Balls Bluff Trail Loop
Swamp, Summit, and Ghost Lake Trail
Cooper River South Park Drive
hits.description:
This is a nice gentle paved trail around the river for rollerblading, biking, running, or walking. There is a dedicated paved path the whole way around!

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the large partially paved parking lot off of North Park Boulevard at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with edge barriers and railings at bridges). It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Wildcat Ridge Hawkwatch Trail
hits.area_name: Wildcat Ridge State Wildlife Management Area
hits.description:
Pleasant walk to excellent overlook at the Wildcat Ridge Hawkwatch

This hike starts where the white blazed 4 Birds Trail crosses Splitrock Rd. Take this trail south, where it begins to a series of ups and downs over sometimes rocky terrain and eventually reaches the hawk watch platform where there are excellent views (you probably won't be alone here on a nice day). Leaving the hawk watch, double back on the white trail for a short distance, then turn right onto an unmarked, but distinct woods road.  Follow this to an intersection with a blue blazed trail, turning right onto it. This trail is interesting as it passes several glacial erratics along the way and eventually reaches Split Rock Rd. Turn left on Split Rock Rd and take it back to your car.

hits.name: Sunfish Pond via Appalachian Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Rocky Point Trail and Grand Tour Loop
hits.description: Well traveled trail combining two loops in Hartshorne Park. River, inlet, beach, and ocean views through the trees.

hits.name: Holmdel Park Trails
hits.description: A great wooded trail and well-maintained, but not a lot of markings. Perfect for a stroll with your dog or a run!

hits.name: Splitrock Reservoir Trail
hits.description: The trail will take you along the reservoir, over ledges, on mountain tops. through deep hardwood forests, as well as swamps. The only road crossing throughout the entire loop is Splitrock Road.  Wildlife abounds in the area, especially song birds. Even though the loop takes you around the reservoir you are not along the shores the entire time. The trails weave all over the area.

hits.name: Lord Stirling Park Red Trail
hits.description: Users have reported that some trails may close when waterlogged.

hits.name: Cattus Island Butterfly Bogs Trail
hits.description: This is a great short hike on easy terrain.  If you're in the area, come out and enjoy this park. You can make the trip as log as you want. You can even enjoy some geocaching.

hits.name: Hewitt-Butler, Carris Hill, Lower and Mine Trail
hits.description: This hike provides excellent view of the New York City skyline and abundant wildlife. Visitors have reported frequent bear sightings in the area.

hits.name: Ramapo Lake and Foxcroft Road Loop
Branch Brook Park Loop
hits.description:
This trail is nice and serene. The path is clean and well maintained for a good walk with gorgeous cherry blossoms in the spring. There are dirt path options for a longer route. 

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Branch Brook Park Drive at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

hits.name: Double Trouble State Park Trails
hits.description: Nicely maintained state park.  Wide, well maintained  trails within a short distance of the parking area skirt the cranberry bogs and historic buildings.  Many other trails traverse the park to its Southern border at Lacey Road.

hits.name: Huyler's Landing and Closter Dock Trail Loop from Alpine Headquarters
Highlands, Wyanokie Circular and Crest Loop
Columbia Trail: Long Valley to High Bridge
Rattlesnake Swamp Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description: This is a great starting point for many hiking trails in the Delaware Water Gap Recreation area. The Rattlesnake Swamp Trail is a great family hike that offers plenty of vistas and changes in environment to keep everyone's attention.  The 700 feet of elevation gain is very manageable and the views along the ridge are well worth the energy.  The Catfish Fire Tower adds to the scenery and provides a good lunch break stop prior to descending into the Swamp trail section of the hike.

hits.name: Lake Surprise Loop via Purple and White Trails
hits.description: Watchung Reservation is the largest nature reserve in Union County, New Jersey and consists of the upper valley of Blue Brook between First and Second Watchung Mountains. For more information visit: http://ucnj.org/parks-recreation/paths-trails-greenways/watchung-reservation/

hits.name: Rocky Point, Grand Tour, Laurel Ridge and Cuesta Ridge Loop
hits.description: Hartshorne Woods County Park has 16 miles of hiking and mountain biking trails, several old military bunkers and a small beach with a fishing pier. The Park is split into three sections from west to east: The Buttermilk Valley Section, the Monmouth Hills Section and the Rocky Point Section.

hits.name: Ramapo Lake Cannonball Loop Trail
hits.description:
This trail is a historic ruins, scenic overlooks, lake

Catch the red on white blazed Indian Rock trail just past the boulder with the Indian painted on it.  Cross stream  on small bridge (may be submerged during high water), You will pass some ruins from the old Dupont gunpower mfg. operation which closed around 1920, then climb. Just after crossing a gas pipeline cut make left onto the Wanaqe Ridge trail (Orange). Eventually climb to several nice viewpoints just off trail. A short, white spur trail takes you to an easterly view. Continue north, then east on the Wanaque Ridge Trail. The trail ends. Make right onto the MacEvoy Trail (Blue). MacEvoy follows pipeline cut for short distance, then turns left into the woods and meets the Cannonball Tral. (Red w/white C) Continue straight on the Cannonball Trail . Cannonball reaches lake and follows gravel rd then returns to woods. Shortly after this you reach the jct. with the Indian Rock Trail. Continue straight on Indian Rock back to car.

hits.name: Kaiser, Appalachian, Rattlesnake Swamp, and Coppermine Trails Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description: This loop can also be entered by taking the Coppermine Trail.

hits.name: Yellow Trail and Highlands Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Rockaway River State Wildlife Management Area
hits.description:
Glacial Erratics, Northern Bog, Limited views, climb the Highest point in the park.

Mahlon Dickerson Reservation is the largest county park in Morris County.  Most of the hike takes you onto the Highlands trail which is part of a long-distance trail that when complete will stretch from the Delaware River to the Hudson River and traverse the NY/NJ Highlands region.  The trail goes through some nice cool valleys lined with Beech trees and the Headley overlook where you get views of the Weldon Brook Wildlife Management area and Lake Hopatcong. After you leave the Highlands trail you get onto to the Boulder trail were you can observe Glacial Erratics.   After going through the boulders you get onto the Pine Swamp Trail.  This trail takes you to the highest point in Morris County and along a Northern Bog, lined with hemlock, Rhododendron, and Spruce trees.  After going along the bog you come to the old Ogden Mine rail bed.  This will take you back to the Parking. 

Sections of the trail are not well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is recommended.

hits.name: Indian Falls, Jackson Brook and Hedden Park Circular Loop
Henry Hudson Trail: Highlands to Aberdeen
hits.description:
A beautiful paved and gravel/sand walkway that spans 14 miles along the shore. There are fishing spots on the rocks, and a small beach to relax at...good for any age or skill level.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Shore Drive at the west end of the trail. Neither of them is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved, wooden boardwalks (with edge barriers), or gravel. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: West Lane and Oak Way Loop
hits.description:
An easy trail to walk, great for people of all ages. Beautiful gardens and wildlife around for photography opportunities. Very clean and the people are friendly.

Duke Farms includes almost 1000 acres of land and is owned by the Duke Farms Foundation (DFF) that was established in 1998 to manage the estate. The Foundation, in turn, is part of the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation.

Accessibility: Please check with your local law enforcement officials about which direction mobility equipment users are supposed to travel on roadways before proceeding. There are 8 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Farm Barn Lane at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. 

The trail surface is paved (with partial edge barriers) and smooth. It is typically 6 to 8 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible picnic tables. The welcome center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Ken Lockwood Gorge Trail
hits.description: This is an unpaved gravel road along the river. You can park at either end of the trail to start.

hits.name: Cushetunk Mountain Blue Trail from Pickell Park
hits.description: Started from Pickell Park in whitehouse. A couple of challenging climbs. From the White Ridge trail you can get a glimpse of the reservoir. Pretty hike, fairly challenging in places.

hits.name: Devils Half-Acre Connector Trail Loop
hits.description:
Trail ranges from a high easy to moderate. 

The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: West, Glen and Eastview Trail Loop
Mullica River and Batona Trail Loop
hits.description: You may have to take a detour at an unfinished bridge on this trail.

hits.name: Allison Park Loop
hits.description: Parts of the trail incorporate the Dyckman Hill Trail (yellow) down the Palisades to the Englewood Picnic area and Carpenter's trail (blue) up the Palisades by the GWB.

hits.name: Rahway and Maple Falls Trail Loop
hits.description: Parking is available on Locust Grove just off Glen Avenue near the Millburn Public Library.

hits.name: Three Mountain Ponds Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description: Inner to outter, to hemlock, to outter to inner

hits.name: Trolley Track, Founder's Walk, River's Edge, and Far Trail Loop
hits.description: Easy, wooded, shady, took 2 kids 5 and 2 with stroller. Suspension bridge.

hits.name: Songbird Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Edwin B Forsythe National Wildlife Refuge

hits.name: Transco to Sawmill Creek Trail
hits.description:
This is a lovely set of easy paved and dirt trails that pass by a lake. It is a popular location for birdwatching.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Disposal Road in the middle of the trail. None of them appear to be van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved or dirt and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less), except for one moderately steep (5-8%) section at about 1.6 miles downhill when going south. 

Trail goers using wheelchair/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the moderately steeper section or to avoid it for safety. According to the park website, all of these trails are wheelchair-accessible. The most accessible portion of the trail is the Lyndhurst Nature Reserve trail: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-jersey/lyndhurst-nature-reserve

hits.name: Cheesequake Blue Trail
hits.description: There's a $5 entrance fee on weekdays between Memorial Day and Labor Day, and a $10 entrance fee on weekends and holidays between Memorial Day and Labor Day.

hits.name: Sunrise Mountain and High Point via Appalachian Trail
McEvoy to Lookout to Hoeferlin Memorial Trail
hits.description:
Some nice views and varied terrain

A very nice hike on two of the lesser used trails in this popular park. Start out blue blazed  McEvoy Trail. Reaching the dam, bear left on the yellow blazed Hoeferlin Trail. Continue on the dirt road and leave the crowds behind by turning left where the Hoeferlin joins the red blazed Lookout Trail (the second left). Here the trail has both red and yellow blazes. The trail begins a short climb to a scenic rocky overlook.  After the overlook, the trail descends  through a stand of  mt. laurel.  Soon you'll pass through an area that's been heavily damaged by gypsy moths. Most of the trees here are dead, giving this section a somewhat haunting look. After passing through another stand of mt. laurel, the red and yellow trails split. Turn left on the red blazed Lookout Trail. There will be some short ascents and descents as it crosses a few small ridges. The trail then descends gently and ends  near the dam. From here, retrace your steps to your car.

hits.name: Parvin Lake Via Long Trail Loop
hits.description: Dogs are not allowed in the campground area or beach.

hits.name: Natirar Park Trail
hits.description:
Natirar Park Trail. Scenic estate with manicured lawns. Leads through woods to picturesque fields with barns.
Park address is:
2 Main Street
Far Hills, NJ.
The address on Highland Ave takes you to a back corner of the park reserved for emergency access with no parking available.

hits.name: Silver Mine Loop
hits.description: The best way to get on the unmarked Stony Brook trail is to walk down the far end of the lot, away from the lake area.  On the right corner there is a trail you can follow along the brook and through the picnic area were you then pick up the Silver Mine Trail.  Continue along the Silver Mine Trail until it branches away from the Brook.  At this point follow the unmarked trail along the Stony Brook.  Eventually the trail comes out to a barn and road. Take the road till it dead ends.  This is were you pick up the Blue Mt trail.  Take Blue Mt trail to the orange Silver Mine.  Then back to the start.

hits.name: Lewis Morris Green, Pink Dot, and Yellow Loop

hits.description: The Woodfield Reservation is a wooded park owned by Princeton Borough. The park is located on a steep slope on Princeton Ridge, north of the town. This trail includes some quiet residential streets. They have very little traffic, but note that there is no sidewalk. It is also possible to loop among the trails within the reservation.

Ceres Park and Nature Preserve
hits.description: Ceres Park is a beautiful landscape of natural growth, hosting a thriving community of animal life that includes mammals, reptiles, amphibians, and many bird species. With an extensive trail system through upland and wetland forests, the preserve can seem much bigger than 52 acres. From the parking lot, a mile-long path through the forest is criss-crossed by many less-defined trails. The trails lead through a diverse selection of plant life to beautiful views of Emerald and Cedar Lakes.

Lawrence Hopewell Trail: Mercer Meadows Segment
hits.description:
The Lawrence Hopewell Trail (LHT) is a 20+ miles bicycle and pedestrian recreational trail and transportation corridor through public and private lands in Lawrence and Hopewell Townships, Mercer County, New Jersey. There are several road crossings necessary to fully navigate the trail, so please use caution.

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Gordon Avenue at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. There are metal bollards at street crossings which reduces the width temporarily. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved portion in the first about 0.6 miles when going north. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 2.0 and 3.0 miles when going north. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type and grade after about 0.6 miles when going north.

Egg Harbor Township Nature Reserve Loop
hits.description:
Pleasant natural-surface trails along the lake with multiple trail options, one along the shore, another higher up in the shade of the trees, and a third through the woods.

The Nature Reserve is a 220-acre sanctuary located in the midst of a residential community in Egg Harbor Township, NJ. It is comprised of three components: An environmental learning center, a lake area, and a wooded forest. Each offers diverse terrain and a unique place to enjoy many activities in a passive and pristine setting, including biking, hiking, fishing, and bird watching. 

To realize its fullest potential, Egg Harbor Township has begun the process of reclaiming and restoring the land with the assistance of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife. The Township has entrusted the Egg Harbor Township Nature Reserve, LLC, a non-profit tax-exempt corporation, to develop the Reserve in a responsible and environmentally sensitive manner for the use and enjoyment of generations to come. 

Thus far, with the assistance of community volunteers, a massive clean-up effort has been completed, a new parking lot installed and a trail system has been created to improve accessibility throughout the facility. The soils of the former mining operation are being stabilized through a gradation plan and the introduction of native vegetation. Hundreds of saplings have been planted to improve the habitat for a wide variety of birds, butterflies, and other wildlife. Interactive trails throughout the sanctuary will allow schools and environmental organizations to study the diversity of plants and wildlife in a natural setting. 

Future plans include an observation deck, gazebo, and ADA-compliant accessibility. Picnic tables, park benches, and informative signs will be placed throughout the Reserve to make it more user-friendly.  In keeping with the passive nature of the park, motorized vehicles and motorized boats are strictly prohibited.  The Environmental Learning Center features a nature trail to enhance the study of trees, gardens, and meadows. It has a canopied building constructed by students of the Eagle Academy, birdhouses, and parking facilities. The 15-acre site has a trail system, recognized as part of the New Jersey Audubon Birding and Wildlife Trail System for its diverse habitat. To date, 48 different species of trees have been identified throughout the Reserve.

The 45-acre man-made lake is fed by subterranean springs and varies in depth up to 20 ft. Five small islands create picturesque scenery as well as a buffer for three vernal ponds. The lake is populated by an abundance of bass that may be fished from the shoreline.  The lake area is surrounded by another 35 acres of upland areas, encircled by both lower and upper-tier trails that are suitable for walking, running, and biking. The uplands also serve as a habitat for numerous wildlife including reptiles, amphibians, wading, and migratory birds, as well as ospreys, and peregrine falcons.  An American Bald Eagle has recently been spotted feeding along the lake at the Reserve! 

The 125-acre oak-pine forest, while mostly undisturbed, has miles of easily navigable trails shared by hikers, runners, and bicyclists. Future plans include an eco-friendly outdoor fitness system with workout stations placed where appropriate. This trail system connects all components of the reserve and also serves as a habitat for deer, birds, rabbits, and foxes.

The Nature Reserve promises to become an environmental and recreational jewel of South Jersey benefiting all members of the general public.

The unpaved surface is very uneven in many places. Trail goers navigating with mobility equipment may need assistance throughout this trail.

Tourne Trail to Osio Rock
hits.description:
Short hike with nice views that passes an unusual stone livingroom.

Catch the blue blazed Hewitt Butler Trail. It climbs a rocky area, then crosses the beginning of the red blazed Tourne Trail. Continue past the red trail  and up a fairly steep slope. Upon reaching the top there are some nice views to the northwest. In an open area to your left is an interesting stone living room, complete with chairs, arm rests, love seats, hassocks and end tables, all made of stone.The view from the living room is a nice one, making it a great place for lunch. Continue on the blue trail and it begins to descend steeply down  a rocky area and crosses the red trail again at the bottom of a rocky ravine. Continue on the blue. It begins to climb again and you'll shortly reach the summit, known as Osio Rock, with excellent 360 degree views thanks to the gypsy moths killing all the trees there. Turn around and retrace your steps back down and catch the red trail in the ravine. After short scramble over rocks its an easy walk back to the car.

hits.description: This double loop trail explores Ringwood State Park. There are many other connecting trails in the area to make the trail much shorter or much longer, along with other trails more appropriate for other activities such as mountain biking.

This area offers several recreational opportunities in an undisturbed natural setting, including hiking, mountain biking, bird watching, bouldering, and horseback riding.

The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: https://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksFacilities/sourland/SourlandMtPreserve.html

Mountainside Park Blue Trail
hits.description: Starting at the parking lot walk west, through gate and past pipeline cut. Begin on the blue with black dot blazed spur trail and in a short distance meet up with the Blue Loop Trail. The trail soon turns right and begins to climb a bit more steeply for a short distance, crests a hill, then descends, crossing the pipeline cut. It then turns left into the woods. The trail crosses a stream and passes an old, log lean-to then comes out on an abandoned road. From there it turns left (north) and begins a fairly steep climb to the summit of an unnamed hill where you will see outstanding views of the area and the NYC skyline in the distance. From here, continue on the blue blazed trail and follow it as it descends the mountain and parallels Route 287. Follow the Blue Loop Trail back to the parking lot spur, and take that to its end at Mountain Ave.

hits.name: Five Ponds Loop
hits.description: This hike is a low elevation gain route that touches five separate ponds. It's a lesser-known trail with a big parking lot.

hits.name: Butler Reservoir
hits.description:
An easy, pleasant walk around a scenic reservoir.

From parking area take blue blazed trail on north side of road. The trail follows the shoreline of the reservoir, then reaches a  large dam. Cross the dam and pick up a blue & white blazed trail. This trail leaves the shorline and begins a short,gentle climb to a ridge where it ends at a white blazed trail. Make a right onto the white trail.  Follow it to where a woods road splits off to the right and bear right onto it. You may note old blazes from the trail on this section. You'll soon come to another dam and pick up the white trail again.
It soon crosses another woods road. Bear right onto this and take  it out to the road. From here you can take the road back to your car, or work your way back on a faint trail along the shoreline, using the road only to cross the causeways.

hits.name: Great Falls of the Passaic River
hits.description: Please check the park website for more information.

hits.name: Mullica River Trail
hits.description:
Great little weekend backpacking trail or big day hike. This is a through hike from Batsto Village to Atsion. This is a super easy hike. It is dead flat and has plenty of water sources. Great intro to backpacking hike.

Leave the car at the Atsion trail head and then walk about 20 minutes to Batsto Village trail head. You can leave the car in the visitor center parking lot, grab a map/ camping permits then hike through the village to the trail head. The trail is fairly well marked (yellow blaze). Camp at the Mullica River Campground. There are well water and latrines available at this site. It is a little tricky north of Mullica River Campground, as there are many cross trails and some blazes are missing. The museum, gift shop, and village exhibits were cool too so make sure to check them out!

hits.name: Brookdale Park Outer Loop
hits.description:
Very pleasant trail in a well-maintained park. This route is fully paved.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of West Circuit Drive in the center of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest sections are at about 0.1, 1.1, 1.2, and 1.8 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Goat Hill North and South Overlook Loop
hits.description: This loop explores both the southern and northern overlook points at Goat Hill. This trail can easily be shortened into a smaller loop or an out-and-back if users wish to only view one of the overlooks.
