West Ridge and Elmdale Loop
hits.description: Park in the Old Short Hills Park car park. Going clockwise, join the West Ridge trail (unblazed), keeping the grounds of Greenwood Gardens to your left. After about 1.1 miles, you'll turn right, joining Elmdale trail (blue blazes). Follow its twists and turns until the 2.6 mile mark. Then you have a choice to either head back to the lot, or continue westwards on the West Ridge trail. If you choose the latter, you'll be doing yourself a favor (and a mini loop of about a mile that gives great views of the West Branch of the Rahway River). You'll rejoin Elmdale to complete.

hits.name: Cedar, River's Edge and Hidden Creek Trail Loop
hits.description: A pleasant hike along a creek on sandy root-filled paths. There are a few stairways and a boardwalk near the end. Due to fencing there is no access to the reservoir. Take the blue, hidden loop to the black diamond, Rivers Edge trail for a little bit more of a challenge.

hits.name: Wildlife Observation Center Trails
hits.description:
A wonderful boardwalk adventure around the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge. There are restrooms available. 

Google Maps can sometimes have a hard time locating the trailhead, look to see it is directing you to the Wildlife Observation Center Access Rd off of Long Hill Rd before departing.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the parking lot off of Long Hill road at the east end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spots within 1 mile of the east end of the trail. The trail surface is wooden boardwalks (with edge barriers and partial railings), or gravel. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches along the route for resting. The visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Lenape Trail
hits.description:
A peaceful, paved path through the woods that follows the river. Easy & smooth.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the small paved parking lot off of North 14th Street at the northeast end of the trail. It does not appear to be van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt or wooden bridge (with railings) and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There are metal bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Roomy Mine via Highlands, Roomy Mine, and Wyanokie Trails Loop
hits.description:
From parking, follow Highlands trail (blue diamond blazes) across the field. 

Take left on Townsend Rd and in a few hundred feet turn right into woods, still following blue blazes. Continue uphill to ridgeline where there are several nice viewpoints along the way. Highlands trail then descends to Blue Mine (flooded). 

From here turn right using the red dot on white blazed trail (do not cross bridge). Follow to junction with the Mine Trail (orange blazes) turn right. Pass Roomy Mine on left. Entry is  forbidden Sept 1 - Apr. 30th due to hibernating bats, but otherwise an interesting side exploration (bring flashlight).

Mine Trail soon meets a yellow and white blazed trail and they climb together to another nice viewpoint. Stay on orange trail, back to the Highlands Trail. Turn left on Highlands Trail and return to the parking area.

Hemlock Falls is one of the most popular sights in South Mountain Reservation. The size of the waterfalls changes seasonally and depending on recent rains. In the winter the falls can freeze solid.

Hobble Falls is a smaller falls name after Hobble Brook which cascades down. 

The Lenape Trail is marked in yellow.

This is a nice long, gentle trail that is pretty popular for walking and biking. There are several road crossings along this rail trail.

Accessibility: There are at least 4 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Atlantic Avenue at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges) and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches and picnic tables along portions of the route for resting.

hits.name: Wyanokie High Point Loop via Otterhole Trail
hits.description: This is a relatively easy hike with slight rocky scrambles. It is well marked trail and has beautiful view of the reservoir and NYC skyline.

hits.name: Grand Parade Loop
hits.description: Starts at the Vistor Center where you see a reconstruction of the soldiers' cabins and watch a 15 minute video on the history of the Park. This trail can connect with several other trails. Goes to the Grand Parade Ground and past some remains of solider huts plus some reconstructions. Well maintained trail, easy and non-technical. Lots of ups and downs on the undulating hills.

Awesome views of the city. Built out very nicely with bike and walking paths both ways for most of it.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the small paved parking lot off of River Road at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with edge barriers and railings) and smooth. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.description:
A peaceful wide trail through the forest with little elevation change. Very shaded.

Accessibility: There are 7 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Eyland Avenue at the northeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved bridges (with railings), gravel, or a natural (grass) surface.

It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There is a double track along some of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Highlands Hilltopper
hits.description: Hartshorne Woods County Park has 16 miles of hiking and mountain biking trails, several old military bunkers and a small beach with a fishing pier. The Park is split into three sections from west to east: The Buttermilk Valley Section, the Monmouth Hills Section and the Rocky Point Section.

hits.description: Eagle Rock Reservation is located on the borders of West Orange, Verona, and Montclair, New Jersey. The Reservation enjoys an unrivaled view of the New York City skyline from the Essex County 911 Memorial. From here you can view the George Washington Bridge to the Verrazano Narrows Bridge. Not all of the trails are well marked, so downloading the map ahead of time is helpful.

hits.description: A walk through Turkey Swamp reveals a primitive wilderness.  Much of the park is forested by pitch pine and oak trees with an understory of bracken fern, pepper bush, blueberry, and catbriar. Many plants and animals associated with the NJ Pine Barrens can be found here.

hits.name: Glassboro/Williamstown Trail
hits.description:
A lovely paved path ideal for road biking or walking/running. Very kid-friendly and shaded for a majority of the trail. 

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lots off of North Delsea Drive at the west end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved or a natural (fallen leaf) surface. It is typically at least 6 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There is a painted dividing line and metal bollards along the trail which reduces the width.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Ramapo Mountains Loop
hits.description:
A lovely hike to nice views and through some old Boy Scout camps.

Take the orange blazed Schuber Trl. Then turn right on the white blazed Millstone Trl, which passes a decent view, then joins the Yellow Trl. Together they cross a road, then the Yellow splits to the right and climbs gently. Soon the Schuber Trl joins and together they pass a rocky area with a scenic view. Reaching the green and white-blazed Old Guard Trl turn left. The trail climbs and crosses a gasline, then the Cannonball trail and the yellow-blazed Hoeferlin Trl. It soon joins up with the red-blazed Ringwood Ramapo. There is a view here that is best when leaves are down. 

Continue on the Old Guard until it reaches the Hoeferlin (yellow blazes) and proceed south. The Cannonball Trail (red w/ white C)  soon joins. A short side trip (red/white blazes) brings you to Matapan Rock which has a decent view. Continue on the Hoeferlin/Cannonball as they descend and skirt Skyline Dr and head back into the woods. The Cannonball soon leaves. Continue on the Hoeferlin to your car.

hits.name: Rocky Brook Trail
hits.description: Nice hike. Goes through open fields and through the woods. The portion through the open fields is one of those trails where they just mow the grass a little shorter than the surrounding grass to mark the trail. There were signs with arrows that pointed the way to stay on the trail. Little pond in there as you get closer to Agress Road.

South Mountain River Trail
hits.description:
The River Trail closely follows the Rahway River to the dam that creates Campbell's Pond. Further downstream the river creates another pond, Diamond Mill Pond.

The ponds are the remains of old industry in the area. A paper mill and pumping station previously stood on the banks of the ponds. 

The River Trail ends at the junction with the Maple Falls Trail.

hits.name: Palmyra Cove Nature Trail
hits.description: Palmyra Cove Nature Park (PCNP) is a 250 acre urban oasis along a highly developed area on the Delaware River. Habitats included in PCNP are wetlands, woodlands, meadows, wild creek and river shoreline, and freshwater Tidal Cove. By protecting this habitat, PCNP preserves the ecological richness of the local environment.

hits.name: Turtle Back Loop and Hemlock Falls
Culver Tower Loop
hits.description:
This is a moderate hike that hits different parts of Stokes - the ridge, valley, and streams.  

You can park at Kittle Field and take the Brown Stony Brook trail up stream to Stony Brook day use area and pick up the Green Tower trail.  The Tower trail heads towards the ridge after leaving the Brown.  It's not bad until after you cross Sunrise Mtn Rd where it heads steeply uphill where you will need some use of hands.  

It ends at the top with the AT, which you can follow a short distance south to the Fire Tower and the view.  Turn back and take the AT north past the Brown Stony Brook trail to the Yellow TInsley trail. The Yellow heads down hill gradually, passing the geologic trail after crossing Sunrise Mtn Rd. Continue on the Yellow past the Red/Blue trails to the road at Lake Ocquitunk. Either take the road to the left or continue a short distance downhill to the blue Blue Mtn loop trail where you will take the left.

If on the road, pick up the Blue trail before the bridges and head to the left through a swampy area. Follow the Blue to the Orange Silver Mine trail. (Optionally continue on Blue to the Brown).
Take the Orange uphill.  At the top you will see the dam for the dry lake, and the trail starts to follow an old road.  Eventually you will see a sign for a short trail to the left and downhill to the Silver mine next to a small creek. Go back to the main trail and follow it to the Brown Stony Brook trail.  Go up stream (to the left) after viewing the falls, and back to the start.

hits.name: Peaceful Partners, Bog and Long Path Trail
hits.description: Please visit the Black Run Preserve website and help support this wonderful place.

hits.name: Ocean Avenue Boardwalk
hits.description:
Dogs are not allowed on the boardwalk or beach May-October. Cycles are not allowed on this route.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Spray Avenue at the north end of the trail. They are not van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is boardwalk or pavement (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: White Cedar Swamp Trail
hits.description: On this gentle trail, you can see an interesting variety of plants that live in the bog. The trail is mostly gravel but there is also a boardwalk section.

hits.name: Turkey Mountain 100 Steps Trail

hits.description: The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: Cedar Trail and Hidden Creek Trail Loop
Manaticut Point and Overlook Rock Trail
hits.description:
This is a steep hike up a lightly used and under appreciated trail to a nice overlook. Because it isn't popular, it can be overgrown at times and poorly blazed (re-blazing is being planned).

Catch the blue blazed Hewitt-Butler trail at the end of the metal guardrail. It descends to West Brook, where crossing can be difficult when the water is high. After crossing the brook it begins a gentle climb to a woods road. The trail turns onto the woods road which soon peters out and the trail turns north and begins to climb the hill. First gently, then quite steeply.  You'll start to see views through the trees to your right. The trail flattens out for a few minutes, then begins the final ascent to Tip Top Point, which involves some rock scrambles that aren't too difficult but may require using all fours. Once you've reached the top there is an excellent view to the east marred somewhat by the scar of a quarry. Return the way you came, or continue on the HB trail for a longer hike.

hits.name: Scarlet Oak Pond Orange and Yellow Loop
Celery Farm Mayor Fitzpatrick Nature Trail
hits.description: This is a short and easy, pleasant walk in a small oasis of green in the middle of Bergen County known region-wide for its excellent birding. Catch the trail behind the kiosk and turn left. It will go through an often wet area and it follows a stream for a way, then a drainage ditch. To your right is the meadow with acres of phragmites spread out before you. Stay on the trail and you will soon pass an observation platform. A good spot to view birds from. The trail winds around the lake and turns east, then south before returning to the beginning. This is by no means a wilderness hike, as you're never far from roads and area homes, yet is worthwhile if you're interested in birding and the area is also known for its many butterflies. Because of its short length its also a great hike for families with young children.

hits.name: Outer Loop (White, Red, Green)
hits.description:
Users have reported that the parking area for this trail is very small, and often fills up early on weekends. No parking is allowed in the adjacent neighborhood.

This route has some steep climbs - be prepared for water crossings also.

hits.name: Baldplate Red, Green, and White Loop
hits.description: This trail follows routes similar to others in All Trails but starts at the parking area off of Church Road in Hopewell Township. This trail offers some of the best elevation gains in Mercer County, with views of the Delaware River from atop Strawberry Hill.

hits.name: Higbee Beach Loop Trail
hits.description: Walked Higbee Beach from the parking area stream Outlet.

hits.name: Columbia Trail: Bartley Road to Long Valley
Windbeam Mountain, Bear Mountain, Board Mountain and Lake Rickonda Trail
Otter Hole, Hewit-Butler, Wyanokie Circular and Mine Trail
New Jersey State Botanical Gardens at Skylands
Break Back Run Trail
hits.description: A great day hike with the reward of a swim in the Wenonah Lake (open Memorial Day to Labor Day). This hike links many of the Woods of Wenonah trails together.  Starting at the Break Back Run Trial, travel SW along a stream. Keep an eye out for deer, Red fox, Red tail hawks and wild turkey. Follow to the Clay Hill trail to the George Eldridge Trail to the Langstons Lake Loop Trail. The Tea House at the N end of the Lake is a good spot for lunch before you follow your footsteps back to the Wenonah Lake parking area.

hits.name: Gloucester Park Trail
hits.description: This is a great trail which is popular for biking, and nice for hiking.  There are many interweaving paths snaking through modest hills between Camden County College and the Gloucester Community Park.

hits.name: Sunrise Mountain via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
The hike starts on the A.T. Parking off of Deckertown. The terrain is fairly easy rolling in the start and rocky at times. You go through some nice hardwood forest with Mt laurel along the sides. Eventually the trail does a short climb to sunrise Mt. On top of the summit there is a big picnic pavilion you can go into to avoid the harsh winds.  

The summit itself is rare due to the harsh climate on top. The trees that grow are small and bent from the winds. In the summer it is not uncommon to see rattlesnakes bathing on the rocks. The views are great. You can see the wallkill valley, NJ Highlands, Pochuck Mtns, Delaware valley, Catskills, and the Poconos.  This is also a great hike to do on snowshoes.

hits.name: Blue Mountain
hits.description:
This is the north part of the new Blue Mountain Trail. Use trailhead at Tinsley trail (yellow).
Take yellow trail northwest (across road) downhill to Flatbrook.  Yellow ends at Blue Mtn.
Take blue to right along river bank. Around two miles you will come to a road.  Take the road to the left across the bridge.  Trail goes into the woods to the right on the other side of the bridge. Follow Blue trail the rest of the way to yellow (Tinsley trail).  Take yellow to right downhill to trailhead. While on Blue trail you will see many other trail signs - light blue Parker, gray Howell, red/brown Cartwright, red Swenson.  But this loop is just yellow to blue to yellow.
There are two good viewpoints around 5 miles on a cliff face just before and after the Cartwright trail.

hits.name: Washington Valley and Chimney Rock Park via Red, Orange, and White Trail Loop
hits.description:
This is a fun hike with nice views and a visit to Buttermilk Falls! Trails are steeper near the falls and there are some muddy areas seasonally.

The trail will also pass over Middle Brook, past Eastern Branch Reservoir, and through the disc golf course at Chimney Rock.

hits.name: Robert Brice Orange and White Trail Loop
Bald Eagle Reservoir Loop Trail
hits.description:
Users note that this trail can often be flooded or boggy due to changing water levels. In this case, downloading the offline maps is recommended to help follow the trail.

Eagle sightings are very common here, so be sure to keep your eyes and ears open to catch a glimpse of these great creatures.

hits.name: Delaware and Raritan Canal Towpath Loop via Mapleton Road
Deserted Village Loop
hits.description: Short interpretive loop with 18th and 19th century history from a colonial farm to guilded age factory town. The first part of the loop is flat and paved, while the second is a woodlands trail with a few small hills to climb.

hits.name: Stoney Brook Trail via Appalachian Trail Loop
hits.description: This loop is great on XC skies or Snowshoes.  Although during times when snow lacks on the trails it is better to use the alternate route by taking the Appalachian trail.  The reason for this is it avoids having to walk paved Sunrise Mt road.  It is a very scenic road but better when snow covered.  On this loop you will go through Hemlock Forest, cross streams and climb on top of the Kittatinny ridge. When doing this on skies make sure you take the Stony Brook trail up the ridge.

hits.name: Ramapo Overlook to Lake Todd and Waterfall Trail
hits.description: Hike to nice overlook, scenic lake, and waterfall.

hits.name: Cushetunk Trail, Yellow, Blue, and White Trail Loop
Manasquan Trail
hits.description: A walk through Turkey Swamp reveals a primitive wilderness.  Much of the park is forested by pitch pine and oak trees with an understory of bracken fern, pepper bush, blueberry, and catbriar. Many plants and animals associated with the NJ Pine Barrens can be found here.

hits.name: Buttermilk Falls Trail
hits.description: This trail begins with a climb to the top of Buttermilk Falls, one of the tallest waterfalls in New Jersey. From there, the trail continues to make a steep climb up to the Appalachian National Scenic Trail for spectacular views of the valley below.

hits.name: Paterson Falls Park Trails
hits.area_name: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

hits.name: Mill Creek Marsh
Laurel Ridge and Grand Tour Loop
Purple/Yellow, Blue/White, and Orange Trail Loop
Patriots' Path West from Lewis Morris Park
Mills Reservation Trail via West Essex Rail
hits.description: Start on the West Essex Trail off Bowden Ave. Take the trail around the reservoir and continue on to Mills Reservation. Complete the loop and make your way back onto West Essex Trail to reach your starting point.

hits.name: Haddon Lake Park
hits.description:
There is plenty of wildlife, benches, and shade along this route. There is a crossing at Kings Highway. Users note that you can avoid the bridge by going a bit farther and then the paved parts loop around. 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Hillside Avenue in the center of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt. It is typically 6 feet wide. The most accessible portion of the trail avoids the bridge with a step marked with a waypoint. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) but there is a steeper section at about 0.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Summit, White Ridge, Copper Hill, and No Name Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Ted Stiles Preserve at Baldplate Mountain
hits.description:
This loop takes users around Strawberry Hill and along the ridge to Baldpate Mountain.

This route takes the unnamed trail back to the trailhead which is a bit shorter than retracing steps back around Strawberry Hill.

Users have reported the unnamed trail is not well maintained and can often be overgrown.

hits.name: Harrisville Pond
hits.description: Hiked past the bog between 563 and 679 then proceeded to the Harrisville Lake  Trail, Ruins, Martha Road, Ruins and back along the Batona Trail.

hits.name: Terrace Pond Loop
hits.description: Crossing the North outlet of Terrace Pond is a bit dicy - lots of water.  The Terrace Pond North trail segment that is North East of Terrace Pond is a bit overgrown and the trail blazes are fading but the way is fairly obvious.

hits.name: Union Transportation Trail
hits.description:
This is a nice gentle gravel trail with occasional hills, surrounded by farms. Shade is limited so make sure to bring sunscreen and water.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the unpaved parking lot off of Millstream Road at the south end of the trail. However, there are at least 4 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off of Monmouth Road. The trail can be accessed using a trail that shares the road with vehicles to the southwest or northwest of the parking lot. It has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges), gravel, or a natural (grass) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Loantaka Trail
hits.description: Very nice paved  path through the woods.

hits.name: Steeple Chase and Ramanessin Trail Loop
hits.description: Nice relatively flat hike through woods, meadows and along the river.

hits.name: Lenape Trail and Oakdale Trail Loop
Crest, Openwood, River and Overlook Trail Loop
Yellow to Cannonball to Pool Hollow Loop
hits.description: This large loop around Ramapo lake starts out easy (and busy) but takes you away from the crowds and onto the Yellow trail. Follow it to the White trail and you'll come across two sets of ruins - the Ramapo Water Tower ruins and the Van Slyke castle ruins, which on a good day will give you great views. Then it's downhill on the White trail to link up with the Red trail as it loops around the backside of Ramapo Lake. This is a much easier section and a good way to relax before tackling the next leg. Take the unmarked road away from the lake and link up with the Yellow trail. This trail is much narrower and not nearly as well marked as previous sections, so keep your wits about you. It will take you up some steep climbs as you make your way North back towards the parking lot. You'll end up on a Yellow / Red trail that will dump you back at Ramapo Lake, where you can take the Blue back to your car.

hits.name: Cedar and Emerald Lake Loop
hits.description: This is a great park to come for wildlife and bird watching.

hits.name: Sunset, Rahway, River, Pingry, Lenape Short Loop
hits.description: Park at Locust Grove lot near Millburn Library. Take the Sunset trail for half a mile, then the Rahway (white blazes) and River trails for 2/5 of a mile. Turn right onto the Pingry trail for 4/5 of a mile. Then join the Lenape trail (yellow blazes) to complete the loop back to the lot.

hits.name: Cheesequake White Trail via Park and Ride
White Ogden Trail, Red and Blue Trail Loop
Grand Loop Trail and Yellow Trail Loop
Roaring Rock White and Blue Loop Trail
Cattus Island Red and Yellow Trail Loop
Tributary, Pipeline, and Maple Flats Trail Loop
hits.description: The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: Delaware & Raritan Canal Towpath - Historic Brearley House to Turning Basin
Delaware and Raritan Feeder Canal (North & South) Trails
Vernon Valley via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
A couple of steep climbs with some long flat marsh boardwalks spaced in between. Great exercise and great views.
Park at the Liberty Loop in Walkill Wildlife Refuge. Head clockwise around the loop for .75 miles until you hit the Appalachian Trail, then turn left and follow it down a long boardwalk. Cross the road for your first steep climb, up Pochuck Mountain.
The Pochuck Boardwalk trail is a nice flat break in between mountains.
The last climb, up Stairway to Heaven, can be crowded. Best saved for a winter day or early am if you want to avoid traffic jams.
After enjoying the view, turn around and head back the same way you came.

hits.name: D&R Canal Towpath: Prallsville Mill and Lock Trail
Marble Hill Ice Cave via Warren-Highlands Trail
Weldon Brook Lake Loop via Yellow Trail
hits.area_name: Rockaway River State Wildlife Management Area

hits.name: White/Yellow and Ranger Trail Loop
hits.description:
3.5 mile loop on the Red blazed Ranger Trail in the Allamuchy Mountain Strate Park.

I parked at the main parking lot at the end of the Sussex Branch Trail on Waterloo Road

hits.name: Haledon Reservoir White Trail Loop
hits.description: Very well constructed and maintained trail loop, with many different water features and benches to observe the main water body, Haledon Reservoir.

hits.name: India Brook Yellow, White, and Red Trail
hits.area_name: India Brook Park and Buttermilk Falls Natural Area

hits.name: Horse Pond Mountain Trail
hits.description: Please check with the park for updates.

hits.name: Allaire Green (Canal) Trail
hits.description: Please note that when you reach Atlantic Ave you must cross the road not on a proper intersection without any pedestrian crossing to continue the trail. You will see a fence not directly opposite where you arrive on the road. The trail does continue.

hits.name: Delaware and Raritan Canal: Frenchtown to Bulls Island
hits.description:
The Delaware and Raritan Feeder Canal itself doesn't extend far above Bulls Island but the bike trail covers the entire distance along converted rail line, meaning the grade is even and the surface is smooth. There are plenty of parking opportunities and there seems to be a picnic bench every mile or so.

You can make a 17 mile loop by utilizing the bridge at Frenchtown to cross over to Uherlerstown and the pedestrian-only bridge at Bulls Island to join the Delaware Canal towpath on the Pennsylvania side of the river.

hits.name: Kincaid Woods Yellow Trail Loop
hits.description:
Pleasant walk through cedar stands, past glacial erratics and old mine

From parking,  proceed southeast over field to edge of woods where you will see the yellow blazed trailhead (about 100 yards from parking). Enter woods on Yellow Trail and continue to junction with yellow/black dot trail. Turn right on this trail and continue uphill.  Black Dot Trail climbs to ridge line, tuns north and eventually ends at the Yellow Trail.  Turn left on yellow and follow back to car (you'll pass an open pit mine along the way).  ====>Alternately, at this junction you can make a right on the Yellow Trail and continue for about 2 miles where the Yellow Trail ends near Bear Rock. You can leave a car at the Pyramid Mt Visitors center or double back. There are some fascinating glacial erratics along this section that are worth checking out<====

hits.name: High Rock Trail
hits.description: Users have reported that this trail can be overgrown with no markings. Please see the park's website for up-to-date information before visiting https://www.nj.gov/dep/njnlt/highrockmountain.htm

hits.name: Trestle Trail and Tilcon Lake Loop
Bald Hill Loop via Ford Road Trail
hits.description: This trail passes by Bald Hill, loops around Hog Pen, and passes through Cathedral of Pines. It uses several different trails including Hillcrest Trail, Mud Hole Trail, Little Bear Trail, and Loren's Loop.

hits.name: Butler Reservoir via Blue and White Trail Loop
hits.description:
Users have reported that the parking area for this trail is very small, and often fills up early on weekends. No parking is allowed in the adjacent neighborhood.

To complete the trail as mapped begin on Blue, turn right on White, then left on Green/Blue to return.  Overall a nice hike.  Some rocky areas and boulders to climb.  A few gates to pass through.  Some skill levels may find the boulder/rocky sections challenging.  Access to the dam is restricted so not much to see of the water.

hits.name: Iron Mine Loop via Sussex Branch Trail
Yellow and White Trails to Mountain Way
hits.description: Tri State Ramblers Monday walk, combined paved & trails.

hits.name: Monmouth Battlefield Trail
hits.description: This is a great intermediate trail which offers multiple starting and ending points. Most of the paths are maintained, but can be overgrown in late summer.

hits.name: Davidson's Mill Pond Park Outer Loop
hits.description: This is a serene route on the outer edges of Davidson's Mill Pond Park, once the site of a former mile.

hits.name: Sunrise Mountain Road
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description:
This road/gate closes seasonally during the wintertime due to snow.

This is a beautiful scenic drive along a paved road. The road weaves through forest for several miles before reaching a viewpoint with a parking lot. If you are looking to hike, the Appalachian Trail also starts nearby.

hits.name: Frost Woods Loop
hits.description: A good local place for mountain biking.  Although the actual park is quite small there are many trail options, some steep but short climbs, a few log jams, jumps and twisty single track.

hits.name: Kinkora Trail
hits.description:
There are benches along this paved and gentle route. Smooth enough to skate on. Half shaded half out in the wide open.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the large partially paved parking lot off of Mount Pleasant Road at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with partial railings) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There are painted dividing lines and bollards along some of the trail which reduces the width temporarily. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Rockhopper Trail and Red Trail Loop
hits.description: Users have reported that the trailhead is difficult to find and that there are 2 different options so it could be confusing. The Dry Run Creek trailhead attaches to the parking lot. The Rockhopper Trailhead is across the road to the RIGHT of the fence.

hits.name: Otter Hole, Wyanokie Circular and Hewitt-Butler Trail
Sparta Glen Lake Trail
hits.area_name: Rockaway River State Wildlife Management Area
hits.description:
The parking lot is not clearly marked. There is a hidden road that leads down to the parking lot from Glen Road. You can spot this road by seeing the stop sign facing the opposite direction from Glen Road. You can start walking on the paved path, and veer left when it changes to a dirt path. Now you will climb uphill. The trail is not marked at all here.  Once you’re up the first wave of incline, you’ll come to another fork.

Stay right and make sure to follow the yellow circle/green dot signs.

hits.name: Paulinskill Valley Trail: Footbridge Park to Sycamore Park
Paulinskill Valley Rail Trail
hits.description: Level easily marked trail with views of Paulinskill Lake, horse farms, wild life.

hits.name: Teetertown Ravine Nature Preserve Campground Loop Trail
Milford Bluffs Trail
hits.description:
The return section of the loop may be overgrown. Some users have suggested to turn around at the southwestern viewpoint and complete the route as an out and back. Also, you may need to bring the app or downloaded map as past the meadow the trails are not well-marked.

Please be respectful of neighboring private property.

hits.name: Surprise Lake Loop from Longhouse Drive
Canal Trail (Long Loop)
hits.description: Really enjoyed the brisk walk! 100s of geese on the lawn, a beautiful playground! There were runners and walkers, families enjoying! The walk on the towpath was going through woodlands, canal on one side river on the other, fall colors, several bridges. Several benches on Nevius St Bridge! watch the beautiful Raritan River. Nevius Bridge is the oldest 1886 recorded metal-truss bridge in the country.

hits.name: Bear Swamp Lake and Rocky Mountain Loop
Landsdown Trail
hits.description:
This trail starts in the north on the southern side of West Main Street in Clinton. It heads by several bodies of water to Lower Landsdown Road in the south. There is a road crossing at Ramsey Road at about 0.4 miles when heading south.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the partially paved parking lots off of West Main Street at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement or packed gravel (with railings at bridges), and typically at least 3 feet wide. The estimated grade is flat (1% or less) with a few gentle (3% or less) sections along the way. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved sections.

hits.name: Lawrence Hopewell, Maidenhead, and Twin Pines Connector Loop
hits.description: This route combines part of three trails that traverse Mercer Meadows County Park in Mercer County, NJ: (1) the Lawrence Hopewell Trail; (2) the Maidenhead Trail; and (3) the Twin Pines Connector Trail. The entire loop includes little elevation gain. Trails are a combination of crushed stone, dirt, and blacktop that are designed for multiple use. They are wide enough for both bikes and walkers / hikers to use just about everywhere. The route shown here includes an optional 3/4 mile spur from the junction of the Lawrence Hopewell and Maidenhead Trails to Rosedale Lake.

hits.name: Cuesta Ridge and Grand Tour Loop
Blue Mountain Trail
hits.description:
The Blue Mountain trail is a new loop through Stokes State Forest.  This is the southern section of the trail. The trailhead starts at Park Office visitor center.
Walk road into park and cross bridge to light blue trail (Blue Mountain) on left.  

Follow for 3 miles past lakes and streams until you join the brown trail (Stony Brook).  Follow brown trail for another two miles until you come to Stony Lake day use area and light blue trail.  Optionally take light blue to right along road, or continue around Stony lake - brown to dark blue (at T intersection) to light brown/light blue and eventually back to light blue ( and black Lackner trail).  Take to left away from lake and follow back to start.

hits.name: Stokes Select Trail via Appalachian Trail
Buttermilk Falls and Rattlesnake Mountain Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description:
From gate at Mountain Road to Buttermilk Falls, Buttermilk Falls Trail, AT (Appalachian Trial), connector trail, Red Maple Trail, Tillman Ravine Trail and Cemetery Trail back to start.

This loop is a great way to explore the area around Buttermilk Falls. There are two waterfalls, a forest stream, a couple of nice views of the Delaware River valley and varied hiking from low elevation forest to ridge top.

hits.name: Tenafly Nature Center Red, Yellow and White Trail Loop
hits.description: This loop is a combination of the Little Chism, Purple, Allison, De Filippi, and Yellow Trails.

hits.name: Cannonball Trail to Ramapo Lake
hits.description:
The parking area and trail access point located on Barbara Drive within Town of Pompton Lakes has been closed by the property owner.  Trail users are no longer able to access the South Ridge or Cannonball Trails from this area.  Visitors are encouraged to utilize the parking area on Pool Hollow Road or either of the established parking areas on Skyline Drive.  

For more information please contact the Ringwood State Park Office at (973) 962-7031.

hits.name: Torne Mountain Loop
hits.description: Short and moderately challenging loop hike with great views of the surrounding area and a unique 'stone living room' to visit.  Dogs and children friendly.

hits.name: Batona Trail: Ong's Hat to Lebanon Fire Tower
hits.description: The Batona Trail is a 53.5-mile (86.1 km) hiking trail through New Jersey's Pine Barrens. This segment runs from the northern trailhead at Ong's Hat to the Lebanon Fire Tower, 5 miles away, and back, through the Brendan T. Byrne State Forest in New Jersey's Pinelands National Reserve. The trail was built in 1961 by the Batona Hiking Club of Philadelphia.

hits.name: Wildcat Loop Trail
hits.area_name: Wildcat Ridge State Wildlife Management Area

hits.name: Schuber, Millstone, Yellow and Todd Trail Loop
Governor Mountain
hits.description:
Easy hike with outstanding views of Wanaque Reservoir

The trail starts at Sloatsburg Rd.  It's a pleasant, easy hike through a mixed hardwood forest with occasional stands of cedar. Two road crossings are involved (the roads aren't very busy). Upon reaching Governor Mtn, you begin a gentle ascent to the summit. From there you will see excellent views of the Wanaque Reservoir. The trail loops around and joins itself north of Governor Mtn. 

For shorter hikes, you can also start at the crossings on Morris Avenue (knocks a mile off the hike), or Carletondale Rd (which reduces the hike to 2 miles RT).

hits.name: Timber Creek Cross Country Walking Track and Dog Park Perimeter Loop
Dunnfield Creek Trail
hits.description: Dunnfield Creek is a popular stream for brook trout fishing. You can fish from the shore, by wading, or by boat. It is marked with light green blazes.

hits.name: Otter Hole and Wyanokie Crest Loop
Overpeck Park River Loop
hits.description:
Nice paved loop through the Overpeck Park along the riverfront. Nice playgrounds, tennis courts, baseball courts, and soccer courts dot the park as you walk along.

Accessibility: There are 12 designated accessible spaces in the large parking lot off of Challenger Rd. at the start of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt, brick, or cement, and typically at least 5 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) uphill and downhill sections at about 0.3 and 1.7 miles when going counterclockwise. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the moderately steep sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Emerson Woods Preserve Oradell Reservoir
hits.description: No parking on Lakeview Terrace. On-street parking available on Summer Street and Ridge Road; then cross main street to Preserve entrance.

hits.name: Van Saun and Zoo Loop
hits.description:
A perfect trail for walking or running. Very well maintained. 

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lots off of Forest Avenue at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at the bridge), smooth, and typically at least 4 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Terrace Pond Blue Loop
hits.description:
As of Autumn 2020, the Terrace Pond section of Wawayanda State Park has been reblazed, and a new trail section has been added, forming a new loop, blazed blue. 

1. Park at the Warwick Turnpike pull off for the blue/green trail running north into Abram Hewitt State Forest, as well as the black-dot trail heading south across the road. 
2. Cross Warwick Turnpike and begin the black-dot (black dot on blue) trail
3. About 1 mile in, go either right or left on the blue loop. Right will take you to Terrace Pond earlier in the hike, but there's no overall difference from a difficulty standpoint.
4. Keep following the blue blazes. When you get to the multi-trail junction, take the blue/red combination, then stay on blue when red splits off.
5. Follow blue back to the black dot to complete the loop, and then retrace the black dot about 1 mile back to your car.

hits.name: Lewis Morris Green Loop
hits.description:
As of April 2021, trails within Lewis Morris Park have been reblazed with different colors. Please follow the AllTrails route and consult Lewis Morris Park website for more information- https://www.morrisparks.net/assets/images/PDFs/Park_Maps/LMmap-REBLAZE.pdf.

If you enjoy the sound of water tumbling over rocks and admiring a beautiful stream, you'll love the Four Bridges hike at Lewis Morris County Park. Along this meandering densely wooded trail, you'll actually cross five bridges over babbling brooks, although the trail is named Four Bridges! No doubt, another bridge was added sometime after the original four.

hits.name: Allamuchy Blue to Red Trail Loop
hits.description: This trail reportedly requires a high clearance vehicle to reach and roads can be difficult to navigate or impassable in winter.

hits.name: Patriots Path: Route 24 to Washington Valley Rd
Elephant Swamp Trail
hits.description:
An easy walk. Also good for bikes and baby strollers. Nice, wide, flat trail. Several benches and trash cans on the path. Farm fields on one side, woods on the other. Creek halfway up the trail is a good spot to let your dog cool off for a few minutes. 
Parking for 5 or 6 cars. Dog clean up bags at trail head in parking lot. Well maintained and clean.

hits.name: Delaware and Raritan Canal Towpath: Bordentown to Roebling Memorial Park
hits.description:
A wonderful trail paralleling the Delaware River. Some areas are narrow.

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of West Park Street at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, wooden bridges (with railings), or gravel. It is typically 3 to 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces).

There is a double track along some of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Dickerson Mine Trail
hits.description: Amazing mines...  the records for the area show the pits go down 40 stories below what you can see.

hits.name: deCamp Wildlife Trail
hits.area_name: Edwin B Forsythe National Wildlife Refuge
hits.description:
The deCamp Wildlife Trail is one of the shorter trails in the Edwin B. Forsythe National Wildlife Refuge, which includes several other conserved areas stretching south to the headquarters just north of Atlantic City.

Official website:
https://www.fws.gov/refuge/edwin_b_forsythe/

For those with kids interested in exploring more of the wildlife refuge, the US Fish & Wildlife Service provides this activity book for ages 4-7:
https://www.fws.gov/uploadedFiles/dragonfly.pdf

hits.name: Skyland's Manor via Ringwood-Ramapo and Crossover Loop

hits.description:
A decently short trail across the Mountain Way Park in Morris Plains, NJ.

Up hill and rocky.

hits.name: The Tourne and Birchwood Lake Loop
hits.description: Park in the lot near the public restrooms off McCaffrey Lane. Walk left onto the Red trail (just past the restrooms) and continue until you join the Purple blazed trail. At about 1.6 miles into the hike, you'll join the Red trail again and head to Birchwood Lake. You'll walk by the Western side of the lake for about a fifth of a mile and then rejoin the Purple trail. At the 2.7 mile mark, you'll reconnect with the Red trail and keep on that until you join the Yellow trail loop (at about 4 miles in) around the Tourne, which will bring you back to the lot.

hits.name: Stephens State Park Orange to White Trail Loop
Norvin Green State Forest Loop
hits.description: Users recommend the offline map to get oriented as several users reported getting confused with all the different trails in the area.

hits.name: Devils Half-Acre, Pipeline, and Maple Flats Trail Loop
hits.description: The Sourland Mountain Preserve is extremely rich in natural resources, and an area that boasts a variety of stream corridors, geologic outcrops, and an ecological preserve that provides a core habitat for a diversity of plant and animal species. The Sourlands is especially known for its nesting birds on the edges of their breeding areas. For more information visit: http://www.somersetcountyparks.org/parksfacilities/sourland/sourlandmtpreserve.html

hits.name: Joe Palaia Township Park Trails
hits.description:
A wonderful paved loop around the Joe Palaia Park. Users have noted and photographed many deer! 

Accessibility: There are at least 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Whalepond Road by the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There is a wheelchair-accessible bathroom by the southeast end of the trail.

hits.name: Oak Ridge Park Trail
hits.description: Former golf course converted into a community park with a paved walking/jogging trail.

hits.name: Lenape Trail: Plainsboro
hits.description:
A beautiful creek and pond-side trail from George Davison Road to Maple Avenue. Bring some bug spray! 

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Maple Avenue at the west end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges), gravel, or a natural (dirt) surface. It is typically at least 4 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type west of the waypoint. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Washington Valley Yellow and Green Top Loop
hits.description:
Very nice hike with the a beautiful waterfall and the brook. 

The park is regional gathering place for birders observing migratory hawks flying south each fall to winter nesting areas.

hits.name: Sterling Ridge Trail
hits.description: Historic ironwork ruins, outstanding views, swamp and streams.

hits.name: Jockey Hollow Green Trail (The Aqueduct Trail)
Five Mile Beach & Wildwood Boardwalk
hits.description:
Beachfront Bike Trail and the Wildwood Boardwalk. Bike riding is only permitted on the Boardwalk till noon but you can bike the other sections all day.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off on East Rambler Road at the southwest end of the trail. 2 of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, or wooden boardwalk (with edge barriers and railings) and smooth. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). There is a painted dividing line along the trail which reduces the width.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There is a wheelchair-accessible bathroom by the center of the trail. There is a playground with some wheelchair-accessible features such as a firm and stable surface.

hits.name: South Amboy Waterfront Loop
hits.description:
This is a paved loop around football fields and softball fields and a gazebo if you park at the Raritan Bay Waterfront Park parking lot. You can make a longer trip along the waterfront by starting at the parking lot to the north.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of John T O'Leary Boulevard at the north end of the trail. However, there are at least 7 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Keenan Way at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. This parking lot has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is paved asphalt, brick, or a wooden bridge with railings. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Island Beach State Park Loop Trail
Wildcat Ridge: Orange Trail
hits.area_name: Wildcat Ridge State Wildlife Management Area

hits.name: Maidenhead Trail to Rosedale Lake
hits.description:
The trail starts at a parking area on Keefe Road in Lawrence Township. It winds through Mercer Meadows County Park, which is a restored natural area; the park's "Pole Farm" district used to be the historic AT&T Oversees Transmission Facility. (The world's first wireless telephone calls were switched through this property in the 1920s, and Franklin Roosevelt's calls to Winston Churchill were hand-connected through a switching station on this property following the attack on Pearl Harbor in World War II.) 

All of the trail segments are well maintained -- mostly crushed stone but a few paved portions in the Rosedale Lake District of the park. It's great both for hiking and biking. The Lawrence Hopewell Trail also joins up with this trail in at least one spot.

Accessibility: There appears to be one designated accessible space in the partially paved parking lot off of Keefe Road at the south end of the trail. It is unclear if the spot is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is wooden bridges/boardwalks (with railings), pavement, or gravel, and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for moderately steep (5-8%) uphill and downhill sections at about 2.3 to 2.4 miles when going northbound. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type and potential tread obstacle at least one of the bridges. There are benches along some of the route for resting.

hits.name: New Wawayanda Lake and Sussex Branch Trail Loop
Henry Hudson Trail: Aberdeen to Marlboro
hits.description:
There are several road crossings along this route and the southern 0.7 miles of the route is along route 79 without a designated bike lane or sidewalk. Please cross safely. Wearing bright colors, a helmet, and using lights and flags are always recommended when sharing space with motor vehicles.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Church Street at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, or wooden bridges (with railings). It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Gravel Hill Trail to Hoffman Station Trail

From the parking area, descend down to the Hudson River before climbing back up the ridge.

Parts of the trail were used by British soldiers entering New Jersey during the Revolutionary War.

hits.name: Delaware and Raritan Trail: Lambertville to Byram
Gloucester Mt. Ephraim Trail
hits.description:
This is a paved trail that is good for walking, running, and biking for all ages. It passes by the Blackwood Caboose. 

Accessibility: There are several small paved parking lots near the start of the trail off Main Street on the south end but they do not appear to have designated accessible parking spaces or striped access aisles. The trail surface is asphalt, cement, or wooden bridge (with railings), and typically at least 5 feet wide. There are bollards near road crossings that temporarily reduce the width. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first mile heading north. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less) except for very steep (over 12%) uphill and downhill sections after about 1.0 miles when going northbound. Wheelchair/mobility equipment or stroller users may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.description:
A short trail with options to deviate from the route slightly for more of an adventure. Very family-friendly.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the small paved parking lot off of Creek Road at the southwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved concrete, wooden boardwalks (with edge barriers and partial railings), or gravel. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. The visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Hudson River Waterfront Walkway: Edgewater
hits.description:
This trail is mostly a dedicated pathway along the Hudson. However, some portions are through parking lots and along the River Road sidewalk.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of River Road at the southwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with partial railings and edge barriers). It is typically 3 to 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Yellow "Poppy Allen" Trail
hits.description: Poppy Allen Trail follows four- to five-footwide, flat, pine needle covered paths and some short sections of sand roads. The trail makes a large open loop, winding through mature pine-oak forest. At the far end, it connects with Falkinburg Trail and leads back to the south end of the group campground road. This trail is open to multi-use outside the day use area. “Poppy” Allen was the first caretaker of Bass River State Forest in 1905.

hits.name: Barnegat Branch Trail
hits.description:
This is a "Rail to Trail" project that will eventually be 15.6 miles from Barnegat to Lacey. Since it is an old rail bed, it is flat and wide. 

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Memorial Drive at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (with railings at bridges), gravel, or a natural (dirt/grass) surface. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Sunfish Pond Loop via Rockcores and Garvey Springs Trails
hits.description: This is a nice well marked trail, although rocky in some places. Once you climb up from the road, you will reach a beautiful pond. No swimming is allowed there. You will be following the green and orange blazes.

hits.name: Horseshoe Bend Orange Trail Loop
hits.description:
Horseshoe Bend Park offers sweeping vistas of the Delaware River Valley, rolling hills, forested ravines and pristine streams, and offers habitat to many wildlife species.  The 452-acre park, to be jointly owned, managed and maintained by Kingwood Township and the NJ DEP Division of Parks and Forestry, offers a venue for horseback riders, hikers, mountain bikers, bird watchers, and others who favor the peace and tranquility of nature. It includes a 10,000-square-foot event center, leash free dog area, and ten miles of trails.
Hunting is allowed at this park during hunting season with a permit for population control. Season typically lasting from September to February. During season if you are visiting wear bright reflective vests for safety. Hunting is not permitted on sundays.

hits.name: Franklin Parker Preserve Yellow and Blue Trails
hits.description: Hike from the 563 parking area on the yellow trail through the bogs, along the river and back along the blue trail.

hits.name: Henry Hudson Bike Trail via Oakshades Park
Manaticut Point and Lake Sonoma Loop

Batona Trail: Ong's Hat to Route 72
Highlands Teal, Yellow and Unblazed Loop
hits.description:
This is a 2.2 mile loop on the a combination of the Highlands Trail (teal), a Yellow trail, and a section of unblazed, mountain biker's trail.

The unblazed section  roughly overlaps the dotted line trail that is published as a trail, but not exactly.  The 'home stretch' section of the trail  back to the parking area was pretty much straight down the hill, were the dotted-line trail that is published  had a few switch-backs in it.  In real life, it was not hard to follow 'the beaten path', as there were no blazes to follow, but maybe during a different time of year, that would not be the case.

hits.name: Secaucus Greenway
hits.description:
This is a nice easy trail with two playgrounds at the beginning and one at the turnaround point. It’s scenic and tranquil with some trees and wildlife.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the large partially paved parking lot off of Millridge Road at the south end of the trail. However, there are several designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off of Koelle Boulevard. The trail can be accessed using a sidewalk and connector trail to the north of the parking lot. It has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is pavement, wooden boardwalk (with edge barriers and railings), or gravel. It is typically at least 4 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the flat grade category (1% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Lake Sonoma and Overlook Rock Trail
hits.description:
Great views, lake, seasonal waterfalls, varied terrain

Take the orange blazed Lake Sonoma Trl west along ridge, then down steep slope and past Lake Sonoma. It then climbs to Overlook Rock. Just before reaching Overlook Rock the white blazed Overlook Rock Trail joins from the right. After enjoying view, continue south on  Overlook Rock Trl and follow to end.  Make right onto blue blazed Hewitt Butler Trail and go NW then N on a woods road. After crossing under the power lines the trail goes back into the woods for 3/4 mile.   Shortly after  reaching another woods road the Overlook Rock Trail joins on right. Turn onto it and follow under power lines again and  onto another woods road. Stay on trail past another rocky overlook. Continue downhill, then  turn right  and follow a woods road, shortly after crossing a  seasonal stream the trail crosses a well defined  and eroded woods road. Turn left on it and follow back to to car.  Alternatively stay on OLR Trail, then make left on Lake Sonoma Trail and retrace steps to car.

hits.name: Tenafly Nature Center Lost Brook Loop
Laurie Chauncey and Lawrence-Hopewell Trail Loop
hits.description: This trail combines a portion of the Lawrence-Hopewell Trail (LHT) with the Laurie Chauncey Nature Trail, which is on the grounds of Educational Testing Service (ETS) but is open to the public. (ETS has long been among the local public supporters of the Lawrence Hopewell Trail.) Part of the Chauncey follows the Stony Brook in a cool, shady valley with healthy trees. A part of it near the Chauncey Conference Center is more flat, but wooded, with grassy trails that can be a bit soggy after wet weather.

hits.name: Allaire State Park East Loop Trail
hits.description: Nice level hike with mountain bike features near the trail. The woods are filled with cool dinosaur figures!

hits.name: Evans Preserve/Highlands Ridge Loop
hits.description: A brook, a pond, a view of NYC, forest & fields in this hike on Chester Township parkland. The trail uses the former Bell Labs "telephone pole farm" and takes you through a restored grassland Wildlife Habitat Improvement Project where birders will find an incredible variety of species.

hits.name: Bunker Ruins via Rocky Point Trail and Battery Loop
Jockey Hollow Yellow and Orange Loop
hits.description: This trail features historic buildings and interpretive signage highlighting the areas role in the Revolutionary War while passing through forests and open meadows.

hits.name: Wyanokie Circular and Will Monroe Trail
Wawayanda Jungle Trail
hits.description: Rhododendron Tunnels, Rare White Atlantic Cedar Swamp, Natural Area

hits.name: Stephens Park Orange, White and White Rumbly Climb Loop
hits.description:
Starting in lot by the Visitor’s Center, head off on the orange trail to the right as you face the Visitor’s Center. Head up hill until you come to the intersection with the White trail

Continue on the white trail (you will pass two intersections with a Blue trail and many unblazed trails).  You will pass under a power line just before you come to the Green trail (3+ miles). Pass the first intersection with the Green trail and continue on the White until you come to the next intersection with the Green.

Head out on the Green trail passing a small lake/swamp looking for the Purple. The intersection is not blazed, but the trail is blazed.  The intersection is a nice looking gravel road. The Purple trail heads up hill on the woods road to a firetower.

After taking in the view, head back down the Purple trail to Green.  Return on Green the way you came (to the right) until you get to the White. The Green loop goes for a distance under the powerline and is impassable, thus do not use the southeast section of the Green loop). Continue on the White to the right on the section.

The White runs for a good distance taking some nice switchbacks up the hillside before running on a narrow path along the side of the hill. Continue on the White until you come to the Red/White trail. Take the Red/White trail to the right, passing the Upper Area until you come to the Red. Take the Red trail to the right and walk parallel to the river (Musconetcong) until you get back to the Visitor Center.

hits.name: Swamp, Crest Loop, and Crest Trail
Greenway Meadows and Ettl Farm Trail
hits.description: This trail connects Princeton's Greenway Meadows and Woodfield Reservation public parks via the Ettl Farm Trail along the Stony Brook and some lightly trafficked residential streets. The route starts at Greenway Meadows Park in Princeton and follows the Rosedale Road bike / walking path Fairway Drive. Turn right and follow Fairway to its end at Wendover. Turn left on Wendover and follow it to its end, where an asphalt path on the left leads to a pipeline right-of-way. On the downhill end of the right-of-way, the trail continues on the left. This leads downhill along a stony path with switchbacks to the Stony Brook. Turn left and follow the trail; it is not blazed or marked, but is obvious along its entire route. About 1,500 feet after the switchbacks is a fork with a high branch and a low branch. Both branches eventually end at the Province Line Road pedestrian bridge, but the upper path allows easier access to the road, which is closed to vehicle traffic in this section.

hits.name: Surprise Lake and Bellvale Mountain Trail
hits.description: This route combines two popular hiking routes into one. First, begin by hiking up and around Surprise Lake. After nearly making a complete loop, begin the trek up to Bellevale Mountain before descending back down to complete the lake loop and heading back down the the trailhead.

hits.name: Ocean Bike Path: Long Branch to Sandy Hook
Franklin Mill Creek Park Trail
hits.description:
This route offers a short and peaceful stroll along the river. The route is a mostly paved pathway.

Accessibility: There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Beverly-Rancocas Road at the north end of the trail. 1 of them is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved, gravel, or a natural (fallen leaf and dirt) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Henry Hudson Trail and Colts Neck Bike Loop
hits.description:
This is a paved bike route on paved trails or in a designated bike lane. Some of the trail shares the road with vehicles, so using reflective materials, lights, or flagging is recommended for safety. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Newman Springs Road at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The route uses a bike lane on the side of the road marked with a painted line for most of the trail.

The most accessible portion of the trail is the paved off-road portion in the first about 1.9 miles. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there are steeper sections at about 0.2-0.5, 2.4, and 4.3 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety.

hits.name: Schuber Trail
hits.description:
Pleasant hike over varied terrain. Streams, waterfalls, nice views.

Starting hike at Skyline Drive makes most of route downhill. Pick up orange blazed Schuber Trail at Camp Tamarack sign.  Trail descends gently through old camp property (ruins to be removed by county someday).  It crosses several streams,  then descends more steeply into Camp Glen Gray (an old Boy Scout camp now owned by Bergen County). It follows a camp road, then turns back into the woods. Soon it reaches a rocky ridge with an excellent eastward view (NYC visible in distance) were it joins the yellow trail. Together they descend to Bear Swamp Rd  where yellow splits left just before road. Turn right onto the road, then left into the woods about 100 yards later. Trail is now relatively flat and very pleasant as it enters Ramapo Valley Reservation, turns southeast and passes McMillan Reservoir. After brief paved section it then turns right off pavement and into woods. It soon passes waterfall on left and ruins on right then follows Ramapo River back to parking.

hits.name: Schiff Nature Preserve Purple Trail Loop
Goffle Brook Park Pathway
hits.description:
A beautiful well-maintained park, with plenty of benches for resting.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the small paved parking lot off of Goffle Road at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with partial railings) or gravel. It is typically at least 4 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 0.9 miles heading south. Storm damage to the trail has reportedly resulted in several areas that are not passable with mobility equipment.

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the section with steps or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible picnic tables and wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the south end of the trail.

hits.name: Stokes Forest Loop Trail
hits.description:
Great Views, clear streams, waterfalls, Good climb, valley walking

This is a long hike so be prepared to be out for a full day.You will start out with an uphill climb to the top of a ridge with great views and a fire tower.  Then you get a great ridge walk to Sunrise Mt overlook were you will get more great views of the landscape.  Then you will descend off the ridge into the flatbrook valley were you will cross many streams and wet areas.  You will end your hike by going up again.  But this time you will pass some waterfalls along the way.  
These are the trails and colors  to take: Green Tower, left on white AT, Left on Brown/Red cartwright, left on red Swenson, Right on yellow Tinsley, left on paved Rd to campsites, left on brown/green Blue Mt, left to old barn,  follow unmarked tr. along stony brook, right on Parking lot to end, left onto green tower to PA.  
Use the Kittatinny Trails map by the NY-NJ trail conference

hits.name: Perrine Hill, Suffin Farm, and Craig Farm Loop

This park and loop were formerly named Olympia Lakes. Please see the park's website for more information. https://www.co.burlington.nj.us/949/Willingboro-Lakes-Park

This route includes paved, gravel, and sand paths and has great views of the lake.

hits.name: Openwood, Hillspur and Longwood Trail Loop
hits.description: Park at the South Orange Avenue (Crest Drive) lot. Keep on Hillspur until you reach the Longwood trail going south, which represents the return leg. Just before getting back to the lot, you'll cross over South Orange Avenue on the southern footbridge.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Daniel Bray Highway at the southeast end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved bridges (with railings), gravel, or a natural (dirt/grass) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

There is a double track along some of the trail, which may have a raised center section and create an uneven cross slope difficult to navigate. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. The visitor center is wheelchair-accessible.

Ocean City Bike Path

The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

hits.name: Thompson Green, Yellow, Orange, Yellow, and Red Loop

Wyanokie Crest, Hewitt-Butler, Carris Hill, and Lower Trail Loop
hits.description:
This hike takes you on a loop that takes you past Chikahoki Falls, the lookouts, and to Carris Hill peak.

From Carris Hill the NYC skyline can be seen on a clear day.

hits.name: Hillspur Trail, Zoo Loop and Reservoir Trail
hits.description: A gentle five-miler that makes a fun loop of most of the north eastern section of the South Mountain Reservation. Start out at the parking lot by Cherry Lane, and then take the Lenape trail (yellow blazes) for a short while until it joins the Hillspur trail (unblazed). Hillspur continues all the way to about the 1.5 mile mark where you then follow the Turtleback Interpretive trail (orange/white) until you reach the Zoo trail (green dot) at the 2.2 mile mark.  After 2.9 miles, you'll hit the Reservoir trail (white). Follow this for a short while until you take a sharp right onto the Turtle Back trail (orange). This tracks the Rahway River and will get you back to the lot. You then have the option to extend the hike by taking the Lenape all the way to South Orange Avenue and back to the lot again.

hits.name: Long Branch Boardwalk
hits.description: Dogs are prohibited from May 1st through September 30th

hits.name: Highlands, Yellow, White, Blue, Green and Orange Trails Loop
Stephens Green, Leeroy, Serpinteen Maze and White Loop
hits.description: Park at a trail head off Station Rd where you will find the tower which leads you on the marked Green trail. Big mostly single-track loop with a final climb from hell towards the end to get back up to Purple and Green trails.

hits.name: Bernadette Morales Brook, Uplands, Eagle, and Deer Trail
High Point and Ridge Walk Loop Trail
Sunset, Rahway and Pingry Trails Loop
hits.description: Park in the lot opposite Millburn Library. Ascend Sunset trail dead ahead and follow it for abut half a mile until you reach the white-blazed Rahway trail. Just before the first mile, turn right onto the Pingry trail (unblazed). Take this for about a mile until you meet up with the Sunset trail again and back to the lot.

hits.name: Hamilton Ridge, Pioneer and Orchard trails loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description:
Start off on the 1 mile 'connector' trail called the Orchard Trail. Then turn right on the Hamilton Ridge trail to walk a short section out to the nearby Old Mine Road parking area.  Then turn around and hike the entire stretch of the Hamilton Ridge Trail til its intersection again on the other end with Old Mine Road.

This trail is essentially an access road for the electric company to access the nearby power lines.  When the trail gets to a point close to the river, the 'woods road' downsizes to  a narrower trail, that then weaves its way through the woods and up the mountains back to its intersection with the Hamilton Ridge Trail. Then make the left back onto the Hamilton Ridge trail and return to the parking area via the Orchard trail.

hits.name: Allamuchy Unblazed to White Trail Loop
Crest, Openwood, Overlook and Summit Loop
Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge Orange Trail
hits.description:
The orange trail is in the Wilderness Area of the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge. 

The "wilderness" designation means that this area offers many wildlife observation, birding, and photography opportunities. In addition, this is a protected area for wildlife. Dog walking and biking are strictly prohibited. Bridges, boardwalks, and power equipment are allowed in very limited situations so deep mud, large fallen trees and flooded trails are common for long periods of time.
