Hikers should wear knee high rubber boots, stay on the trail, and avoid widening the trails by skirting the mud spots.

hits.name: Atsion Lake Loop
Mountainside Park Red Trail to Blue Trail Loop
Kresson Trails: Full Loop
hits.description: This route follows: Blue, Red, Yellow, Purple, White, Green and Orange Trails. For more information visit: https://southjerseytrails.org/2013/03/19/kresson-trails-cherry-hill-nj/

hits.name: Pakim Pond Trail from Shinns Road
Wood Duck Trail
hits.description: The trail is flat and well maintained. The main purpose of the trail is for Wildlife viewing. There trail takes you through extensive wetlands, hardwood forest, and some fields. Along the route you will pass many interpretive signs explaining the local plants, Insects, Mammals, Rreptiles and Amphibians that you can find in the area. On warm days you can find Turtles bathing on logs or snakes on the trail.  The best time to hike here is Spring and Fall.  Eventually the trail ends at the bank of the Wallkill River. A great place for Kayaking. The current of the river is so calm that you can paddle both up and down river with ease. It is also great to get out on this trail in winter with Cross Country Skis or snowshoes.

hits.name: Red, Openwood, River, Pingry, Lenape, and Bear Lane Loop
hits.description: This fairly level trail passes creeks and rocky outcroppings with some elevation gain in the last half mile.

hits.name: Cape May Boardwalk
hits.description: Dogs are not allowed on the Cape May boardwalk from April to October annually.

hits.name: Hibernia Brook Trail
hits.area_name: Wildcat Ridge State Wildlife Management Area
hits.description:
The Wildcat Ridge State Wildlife Management Area is over 6,300 acres popular with hikers and bird watchers, migratory birds can be seen passing through the area each spring and fall.

The Hibernia area was home to many mines and the forest is still filled with past evidence of mining activity in the area.

hits.name: Thompson Park White, Green, Yellow, Red, and Blue
hits.description: Well marked trail that is nicely maintained.   Lots or deer, squirrels, chipmunks and birds.

hits.name: Cuesta Ridge, Grand Tour, Rocky Point and Battery Loop
Orange (CCC) Loop
hits.description: This trail traverses various habitats including cedar swamps, pine plantations, and pine-oak forests. Also along this trail are the site of the Civilian Conservation Corps camp, and the Forest Firefighters Memorial.

hits.name: Chestnut Branch Park Nature Trail
hits.description: Hiked around the ball field down into the Chestnut Branch Ravine and back up.

hits.name: Old Egg Harbor Road Bike Path
Jefferson Lake Bike Path, White and Teal Loop
Hoffman Park Trail
hits.description:
This hike starts at Baptist Church Rd entrance and proceeds to Mechlin Corner entrance and back using the outside trail loop.  One can start this at the parking lot, but make sure to check out the views on the driveway in.

Start at Baptist Church Rd and proceed down the driveway, which offers a fantastic view of the hills to the north and Spruce Run reservoir.  Just past the parking lot head downhill using the grass path.  At the bottom of the path turn right on the paved road.

Where the paved road splits next to Manny’s pond, turn left and follow the paved road past the pond.  Many birds including geese, ducks, herons and kingfishers may be found on Manny’s pond. Continue straight past the pond until the paved road ends and makes a 180 degree turn.  Do not follow the path towards the silo and barn, but instead follow the gravel path as it curves through the fields. The gravel path passes several ponds as it heads into the woods.  Take the first left and head east.  Follow this path through the woods, and fields ignoring all the side paths until you get to Mechlin’s Corner road.

Retrace your steps back until you come to the first path on your left at the edge of the field.  Follow this path south as it curves around and heads straight through the woods.  Again ignore all the side paths until you get back to Manny’s pond.Continue back up the hill, but stay on the road this time.  When you get to the top of the hill turn right and proceed back to Baptist Church Rd.

hits.name: Cattus Island Main Trail and Hidden Beach Trail Loop
hits.description: From the parking area, follow the main trail until it reaches the Hidden Beach Trail which is marked with orange blazes.

hits.name: Monks Trail from Beech Road
hits.description: For a shorter hike this one has a moderate elevation change with some nice scenery.  Following the White Blaze to complete a circle. At the halfway point take the White/ Black Square Blaze for the great lookout. Enjoy!

hits.name: Red Bank Battlefield
hits.description:
This is a very short walk along the Delaware River up through the monument and past the Old Homestead. Great place for a quick outing and to let kids play.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Hessian Avenue at the southeast end of the trail. One of them is van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with partial railings). It is typically 3 to 6 feet wide. 

The most accessible portion of the trail avoids the stairs marked with a waypoint. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest section is at about 0.5 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Orange Trail and Purple Trail Loop to Lake Surprise
Wyanokia Circular and Crest Trail from Boy Scout Lake
hits.description:
Wyanokie Circular (red on white) to Will Monroe Loop (pink) to bushwhack to Wyanokie Circular (red on white) to Outlaw (orange) to Wyanokie Crest (yellow) to joint Wyanokie Crest and Highlands (yellow and teal) to Wyanokie Crest (yellow) to Wyanokie Circular (red on white). 

Parts of this trail loop are off trail.

hits.name: Batona and Old Batona Trail Loop
Orange Switchback, White and Yellow Loop
hits.description: If you are comfortable with the distance, this loop should be a nice walk in the woods; it is moderately flat with fair amount of nice surfaces. While the path is mostly evident, pay attention to the turns as they are very poorly marked.

hits.name: Crater Lake
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Village Park to Reed / Bryan Farm
hits.description: This is an easy hike, pretty flat, through the Mercer Meadows "Pole Farm District" and "Farm District." Good in the evenings at sunset. Lots of wildflowers in the spring and fall especially. There's a nice observation platform for wildlife viewing.

hits.name: Riverfront Park Loop
hits.description:
This is a loop around two adjacent parks in Hackettstown.  (Riverfront Park and SandBar Park/Alumni Field). It's a combination of the paved path directly ringing some of the soccer/ball fields as well as some of the gravel-based trails in the nature trail of Riverfront Park

Accessibility: There are at least 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Seber Road at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement (with railings at bridges) or packed gravel, and typically at least 4 feet wide.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a moderately steep to steep (6-12%) uphill and downhill section from about 0.8 through 1.0 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Terrace Pond West Trail
hits.description:
This trail leads to the quiet Terrace Pond with great panoramic views. 

The trail is quite rocky in many places, so proper hiking footwear is encouraged.

hits.name: Plum Falkinburg Trail and Yellow Poppy Allen Loop
hits.description: This trail traverses various Pine Barren habitats including a Pine Plantation planted in 1920 and 1930’s by the CCC.

hits.name: Dogwood Hollow
hits.description: This is a peaceful woodland trail, running alongside streams. It is easy to connect to the short and easy Holly Grove Trail, or can be made into a much longer and more challenging hike by continuing on onto other neighboring trails.

hits.name: Passaic River Trail - Pioneer Path (Blue and Yellow)
hits.description: This trail follows along the Passaic River, connecting New Providence and Summit.

hits.name: Copper Hill Trail and Baldplate Mountain Loop
PSE & G to Dunham Trail
hits.description:
Flat, easy trail to do with kids and/or dogs (on leash) along the Ho-Ho-Kus Brook. It is short but well-shaded and enjoyable.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Northern Parkway at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement or a natural surface and typically at least 3 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Brendan Byrne Forest Loop
hits.description: Partially paved loop through the forest. Great for a mountain bike or a street bike with medium width tires, but if you ride a road bike with narrow tires you will get bogged down in the sandy sections.

hits.name: Ranger Trail Loop
hits.description:
3.5 mile loop on the Red blazed Ranger Trail in the Allamuchy Mountain Strate Park.

I parked at the main parking lot at the end of the Sussex Branch Trail on Waterloo Road

hits.name: Andover Loop Trail
hits.description:
The Andover Loop trail is a combination of  sections from the Sussex Branch Trail, the Hillside Park/Goodale Trail, and trails in the Kittatinny Valley State park.  There are several other alternative parking spots around the loop that can be used to start the loop

The trail is well blazed, and it really good shape and pretty frequently used.  There is one small section along Limecrest Road that you have to leave the former rail trail to walk along the road for a stretch to avoid private property.

hits.name: Long Branch, Ocean Avenue, & Asbury Boardwalk to Avon-by-the-Sea
hits.description:
An adventure along the New Jersey coast with part boardwalk and part neighborhood sidewalk. Cyclists must stay in designated lanes. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the small paved parking lot off of Ocean Avenue North at the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved (with partial edge barriers and railings). It is typically 4 to 8 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Laurel and Cuesta Ridge to Grand Tour Loop
New Jersey Brigade Trail (Patriot's Path)
hits.description: In and out lollipop loop running NE to SW along a very hilly section of the Patriot's Path.

hits.name: Cherry Ridge Loop
hits.description: Route Overview: From the Parking lot, Blue (Wingdam) - Yellow (Double Pond) - Red (Red dot) - Cherry Ridge road - Red (Old coal) - Unmarked trail - Green (Turkey ridge) - Green (Pines) - Unmarked trail - Cabin Trail road - Cherry ridge road - Unmarked trail - White - Cherry ridge trail - Yellow (Laurel pond) - Orange (Sitting bear) - Blue (Wingdam)

hits.name: Blue Mountain Lake and Woods Road Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description: This route goes around Blue Mountain Lake, goes toward Rattlesnake Mountain, passing Hemlock Pond and Crater Lake with a short stretch on the AT. Stop at Indian Rocks and then proceeded down Woods Rd.  One could cut 2+ miles out by taking the Buttermilk Falls trail to the AT, but here you continue on to an unmarked trail (after the switchbacks, and just before a small creek). It is a nice path through an hemlock grove past a swampy area. Continue on the AT until it makes a sharp right. Then take the trail straight ahead to a gravel road which brings you to Crater Lake (there is a side trail to the lake edge). Head up hill on the Orange, cross the AT and then down hill near to Hemlock Pond where you pick up the Blue trail. Turn right onto the Red Trail near Blue Mountain Lake and finish the trail along the lakeshore.

hits.name: Lake Valhalla Overlook via Yellow, Orange, and Green Dot Trails
hits.area_name: Pyramid Mountain County Natural Historic Area
hits.description: This is a perfect quick hike to beautiful views of Lake Valhalla and NYC in the distance. Rarely crowded great spot to bring your dog!

hits.name: Otter Hole, Carris Hill, Yoo-Hoo Point, and Wyanokie High Point Loop
hits.description:
A long loop through Norvin State Park, taking you to the summit of Carris Hill and to a few lookout points facing east. On sunny days, skyscrapers from Manhattan are visible!

The hike is performed counter-clockwise. The trails are rocky but they make the route more entertaining. It can be slippery with mud and fallen leaves during Fall. The steepest climbs are early in the hike, leaving the last 30-40% relatively flat and quick.

Since this park is very rocky and hilly, balance is very important. At the beginning of the hike is a large creek that must be crossed over rocks.

hits.name: Black Run REÍ Coop White Trail
High Mountain via Ringwood Ramapo Trail
Matapan Rock, Lake Vreeland and Millstone Hill
Ramapo Lake from Pool Hollow Trailhead
hits.description: The parking area for this trail is simply a pullout with room for only 2-3 cars. Additional parking for Ramapo Lake is available on Skyline Dr.

hits.name: Lake Papaianni
hits.description:
A paved adventure around Lake Papaianni Park. Beautiful flora and fauna.

Accessibility: There do not appear to be any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Chestnut Street at the southwest end of the trail. However, there are 4 designated accessible spaces with striped access aisles in the paved parking lot off of Central Avenue. The trail can be accessed using a paved connector trail to the east of the parking lot. It has been marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is paved (with partial railings). It is typically at least 5 feet wide. The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest sections are at about 0.0 and 0.2 miles when going counterclockwise. 

Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms at the southwest end of the trail.

hits.name: Baldplate Ridge and Pleasant Valley Trail
Lower Forge and Mullica River Camps
Gravel Hill White Trail
hits.description: Nice trail, but half of the loop is unmarked.  Paper maps at kiosk show full loop.  Very muddy in places.

hits.name: Union Lake Trail
hits.description: Be advised, this area is used during hunting season. Check ahead and wear orange.

hits.name: Lyndhurst Nature Reserve
hits.description:
This trail goes through some forests and open lawns. There nice spots to enjoy the water, wildlife, and birdwatch on benches and a natural amphitheater 

Accessibility: This is the most accessible portion of the Transco to Sawmill Creek trail: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/new-jersey/transco-to-sawmill-creek-trail There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Disposal Road in the middle of the trail. None of them appear to be van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is packed dirt and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the route for resting. According to the park website, this trail is wheelchair-accessible.

hits.name: Crater Lake and Hemlock Pond
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Delaware and Raritan Trail: Bulls Island to Lambertville
hits.description:
Smooth and even trail along converted rail line. (7 miles)

The middle section of the Delaware and Raritan Feeder Canal trail deviates from the canal itself and runs for the most part on converted rail line. This doesn't change the surface of the trail, which remains smooth and level. Hostorically, this section of the canal was to supply water to the lower, more commercial sections of the canal. 

Utilizing the pedestrian-only bridge at Bulls Island and the bridge between Lambertville and New Hope to join the Delaware Canal towpath on the Pennsylvania side make a loop of 13.6 miles.

hits.name: Nassau and Bear County Loop Trail
William Hoeferlin, Wayward, Iron Mountain, and Black Eagle Loop
Cedar Bonnet Island
hits.description: Cedar Bonnet Island has a gravel path along the bay and marsh lands.

hits.name: Traction Line Recreation Trail
hits.description:
This paved trail runs from Fairleigh Dickinson University to the Morrisville National Historical Park.

Accessibility: There are 6 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Dreyfuss Road at the southeast end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 10 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

hits.name: Kuser and Copper Hill Trails Loop
Elephant Swamp Trail: 538 to Reed Branch
Mountain Lakes Nature Preserve White Trail Loop
Field Loop Trail to Dogwood Trail Loop
Margate-Ventnor Boardwalk Path
hits.description:
Linear path on sidewalk and boardwalk (complete) sea side.
All season ( chose the direction according with the strong wind )

hits.name: Otterhole, Wyanokie Crest, Chikahoki Falls, Hewitt-Butler, and Carris Hill Trail Loop
hits.description:
This route starts and finishes at the outer parking lot for the highlands natural pool on Snake Den Road. 

The back end of this route hits some of the best viewpoints in the NJ Highlands including Wyanokie High Point, but makes you earn them first!

A gradual climb over the first two miles eventually descends over the next two miles ending at Chikahoki Falls, a perfect mid-point spot to take a break and enjoy a snack.

From here the next mile is a winding 700ft ascent up Carris Hill, the most strenuous of the hike.

After reaching the top of Carris Hill you will continue along the ridge line passing some remarkable pitch pines along the rocky top of the hill.  Yoo Hoo point is next, in the distance you’ll see Wyanokie High Point. 

A short climb up and up again takes you to the 360 views that it’s known for. 

You will descend back down the way you came on the Hewitt-Butler Trail (blue) until you reach Snake Den road and back to the parking lot.

hits.name: Batona Trail and Jersey Central Lines from Carranza Memorial
hits.description: Hiked down the old railroad bed until the first fire road crossing and came back along the Skit Branch via the Batona Trail to the campground.

hits.name: Lockatong Wescott Preserve Trail
hits.description: Lovely creek side train begins on Raven’s Rock-Rosemont Road, immediately adjacent to the iron truss bridge over Lockatong Creek. Easy trail proceeds through Hunterdon Land Trust property and crosses on to Wescott Preserve of Hunterdon County Park System. Trail veers sharply uphill and into a hardwood forest dotted with old stone walls. Eventually emerges into grass fields , where you can create a loop to return to the parking area.

hits.name: Crossover and Ringwood-Ramapo Trail Loop
hits.description:
This loop is great for hiking or mountain biking, climbs are rewarded with pleasant views. 

The New Jersey Botanical Gardens are also accessible from the trailhead.

hits.name: Highlands Trail and Morris Canal Greenway Loop
Purple, Yellow, and Blue/White Trail Loop
Blueberry Hill Red Trail
Wading River: Godfrey Bridge Rd to Bodine Field Rd
Roosevelt Park Loop
hits.description:
This is a well-maintained paved path. 

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Pine Drive at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 8 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle (5% or less) grade category but there is a steeper section at about 0.3 miles when going north. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety.

hits.name: Stephen R. Gregg Bayonne Park Loop
Bicentennial Park Trail
hits.description:
A short adventure around the park with some river views.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Hardenburg Lane at the southwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt, gravel, or a natural (dirt, rock, and root) surface. It is typically at least 3 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). The most accessible portions of the trail are the paved areas of the park. 

The entire trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces.
There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible bathrooms by the center of the trail.

hits.name: Cataract Park - Red Trail
hits.description: 1.7 mile out and back on the Red Trail in Washington Township's Cataract Park. The way the trail is blazed now you come in to the waterfall a little higher up the mountain. Be advised some of the red marker blazes are painted on rocks on the ground.

hits.name: Appalachian Trail: Catfish Tower Entrance to Delaware Water Gap
Creek-Ferramonte, Dickerson Mine, Canfield Mine, and King Mine Loop
Iris Trail via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
Park in the Appalachian Trail lot (about 1/3 mile before High Point State Park lot). Follow the blue-blazed trail .25 mile, turn right on red/white blaze trail .2 mile til the junction with AT. Turn left. Follow AT along east ridge. It will swing to the west ridge. Views of Lake Rutherford and swamp will be on the left. 

There will be a large rock formation (Dutch Shoe Rock) on the left with great views. It's a good place to take a break. Continue on AT, turn left at signs for Rutherford Shelter. This cuts a bit off the trail and takes you past AT shelter. Follow the unmarked trail (easily found in front of shelter) through the woods to the red/white marked Iris Trail. Follow this trail past the lake and all the way back to junction w/blue blaze - turn right and you are at the parking lot. Very well marked and pleasant hike.

hits.name: Lake Absegami via Joe's Trail
hits.description: This trail is named for Joseph N Trujillo, 1920-2009, army veteran of three wars, hike leader, activity coordinator, and president of the Outdoor Club of South Jersey. It follows the southern shore of Lake Absegami.

hits.name: Rocky Brook Trail
hits.description: This is an out-and-back trail that follows Rocky Brook, a tributary of Stony Brook. The trail starts from a gravel pull-off along the westbound side of Route 518; about six cars can fit in this parking area. There are about six river crossings, which may be difficult to cross when the water level in Rocky Brook is high. The trail passes the site of Snook Mill Dam, a mill dam owned by the Snook family, who held land in this area starting from the 1760s. The northern end of the trail, which is along Snydertown Rd in East Amwell, lacks parking. This hike can be combined with nearby Cedar Ridge Preserve, which has parking lots on Stony Brook and Van Dyke roads.

hits.name: Orange/Blue Patriots Path and Grand Loop Trail
Ball Mountain Overlook via Mine Trail
Grand Loop Trail, Primrose Trail, Yellow, and Orange Trail Loop
Cattus Island Main Trail
hits.description:
This hike follows the main trail from the parking lot to Barnegat Bay.

There are several osprey nesting platforms along the trail.

hits.name: Hidden Lake Trail
hits.description: You may need a 4x4 vehicle to reach the start of the trail, cars may not be able to make it.

hits.name: Crater Lake
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Kittatinny Valley Southern Loop
hits.description: This is a loop on the southern part of the Kittatinny Valley State Park.  The trails follow Blue, Orange, Red and a few unblazed roads.

hits.name: Hemlock Falls via Summit, Balls Bluff, Lenape, and Openwood Trail Loop
hits.description:
Overall a relatively shorter hike but good views from the summit and view of the waterfall. 

The trail is mostly well maintained with a few sections of stairs and rocks.

hits.name: Flagg Kirkland Trail Loop
hits.description:
Nice area in the woods with several small streams to cross. Gentle ups and downs plus different environments make for a nice hike.

Start from furthest parking lot in South section
1.	From end of parking lot take Blue Diamond trail down into the woods
2.	Pass first intersection with Blue trail to the right – continue straight ahead.
3.	Follow the Blue alongside the creek until you meet the White trail
4.	Take White to the left along Burke’s Run to the Orange blazed trail
5.	Take the Orange to the left and south for a short while until it meets the Yellow Diamond blazed Flag Kirkland Trail.
6.	Take the Kirkland trail south wandering through the woods until it meets Fairview Road.
7.	Cross Fairview Rd. and continue on the Kirkland.  Eventually it heads north and crosses Fairview Rd again. (When there are no leaves on the trees one can see the Delaware River below to the west)
8.	The Kirkland wanders through the woods turning east before intersection the Orange trail again.
9.	Take the Orange trail to the right and follow the path along the park edge
10.	Eventually it crosses the entrance road and the White trail.  Stay on the Orange trail along the creek until it meets the White trail again.
11.	Leave the Orange and take the White to the left until it meets the Blue.
12.	Take the Blue back to the parking lot.

hits.name: Frelinghuysen Arboretum
Lake Tamarack
hits.description: This is a nice, short loop with some interesting features- lake, dam, wood tent structure and ruins. The portion of the hike around the lake is not blazed (accessed from the orange trail).

hits.name: Wildcat Ridge, Fly Way Spur, and Four Birds Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Wildcat Ridge State Wildlife Management Area
hits.description: Nice 4 mile moderate loop with views from Hawkwatch Overlook.

hits.name: Alpine Scout Camp - Fort Lee via the Shore Trail
hits.description: You can learn a lot of history walking along this trail. Beware of the tide.

hits.name: Lawrence Hopewell, Bryan Farm, Maidenhead Trails Loop
hits.description: This loop uses parts of the Lawrence Hopewell Trail, Farm History Trail, Reed / Bryan Farm Trail, and Twin Pines Connector Trail in Mercer Meadows County Park, New Jersey. The trails are popular for both hikes and bikes. Mercer Meadows was the site of the first transatlantic wireless telecommunications transmitter from the early 20th century until its decommissioning in the 1970s.

hits.name: Seeley's Pond White Trail Outer Loop
hits.description:
The White Loops winds through the 2,000 acre Watchung Reservation. The park is also home to the Trailside Museum, the first nature museum established in New Jersey.

Visitors can also visit the deserted village of Feltville where 10 historic structures are still standing.

hits.name: Batona Trail: Route 532 to Carranza Road
Beaver Pond to Crater Lake via Appalachian Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Mike Merdinger Memorial Trails Red Trail
hits.description: Effortless stroll through the heart of Hillsborough, NJ, featuring a mix of sprawling farmland views and dense woods. Red Trail begins traversing the border of the Foothill Acres Nursing Home property and continues through grassy, wooded terrain with little to no elevation. About a half mile in the trail opens up to what was once a local farm. Then the trail meanders alongside a horse stable, back to the main open space and finishes with a walk through woods.

hits.name: Indian Cliffs
hits.description:
Head north on the Yellow blazed Timberbrook trail from the parking lot (not the woods road). Follow the trail to an overlook of Timberbrook pond, where the Yellow meets the White blazed Four Birds trail. Take the Four Birds trail to the right (east) heading gradually uphill. On the downhill side you will cross several trail (Green, Pink), but continue on the White until you find the Blue. Take the Blue downhill to Misty Pond. Head around Misty Pond ignoring the other trails.  

You will eventually cross Charlotteburg Road - an old woods road. Cross it. There will be a rock wall in front of you. Follow the Blue trail as it heads up hill. At the top in Indian Cliffs with a beautiful view of the north end of Splitrock Reservoir and Misty Pond to the right. 

Please turn around at the private property sign at the end of this route marking entry into Camp Winnebago property.

hits.name: Riverwinds Nature Trail
hits.description: Hiked the nature trail circuit.

hits.name: Paulinskill Valley Trail: W Crisman Rd to Brugler Rd
North Brunswick Community Park Loop
hits.description:
A convenient place to get 2 miles in. Great for cycling or walking with pets, friends, and family.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of George's Road in the center of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved bridges (with railings), gravel, or a natural (grass) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Watershed, Meadow/Pond, and Stony Brook Trail Loop
Point Mountain Reservation - North to South
hits.description:
Point Mountain consists of three sections.  Most people only do the Central section, but this hike covers all three.

1.	The hike starts at the parking lot off Old Turnpike Rd - walk from the parking lot to the fields to the west and follow the Orange trail (on map, but not blazed in the fields. May want to look at Satellite map to see the fields).  Head counterclockwise in the field doing two sides of the field and take the second opening into the second field on your right.  Continue counterclockwise in this field heading uphill.  After you do three sides of the field, you will see at the corner an opening in a rock wall going into the woods.  If you look carefully, you can see Orange blazes in the woods.  Follow the Orange trail, which starts out parallel, to the field.  Eventually near the last field you will see the Orange trail turn to the left but continue straight (might be blazed white and orange at this point).  Shortly you will come to a trail going to your left - this is the White trail.  To the left goes back to the parking lot.  Head straight on White following the blazes uphill.

2.	Eventually the trail intersects the start of the Blue trail on the left.  Take this trail uphill.  The Blue will meet the Red at an old wood road.  Take the Red to the left, which will cross a huge stonewall which is almost straight up and down on the far side.  Shortly you will intersect with the White again.  Take the White to the left and follow it to the top (1000 ft. elevation, but no view due to the trees), before following it downhill.

3.	At the bottom of the hill, you will cross Penwell Rd and enter the Central section of Point Mountain.  The White renters the woods to the left.  Continue on White and cross Beatty's Brook before heading uphill through a large patch of ferns.  Continue on White until you meet the Orange trail intersection.  Take Orange to the right and downhill to the fields.  Stay on the edge of the field (clockwise) heading downhill until you meet Blue.  Follow Blue into the woods and along the Musconetcong River - nice flat beautiful walk.  Make sure to take the section closest to the river.

4.	Eventually you will come to the road by an old iron bridge.  Head away from the river to the parking lot. Take Blue into the woods until you intersect the Orange again (should be straight ahead).

5.	Take the Orange path up hill.  You are now climbing Point Mountain - about 450-foot elevation gain in half a mile, but not a bad trail.  At the top, there is a beautiful view to the North.

6.	From the top head down the backside and find the Yellow trail.  Take the Yellow trail to the road (Point Mountain Road) - note just before the road there is a fork - take the right branch.  There was a huge tree covering the trail at this point so carefully make your way down to the road.  If you did this correctly, you will see the Yellow Blaze on the tree across the road.  If not you will have to look for it as the trail is faint at this point.

7.	You are now in the South section of Point Mountain.  Follow the Yellow trail away from the road and uphill until you again intersect the White trail.  Take the White trail to the right.  Follow the White trail through the woods and eventually you will come to open fields.  Continue through the fields until you come to the parking lot on Mountain Top Rd and the end of the hike.

The White trail is one continuous trail from the starting lot to the final lot, but it misses most of the highlights of the area.

hits.name: Woodland, Summit, and WP Double Track Trail Loop
hits.description:
This loop is mostly wooded and passes over a few small creeks.

The High Mountain Park Preserve is bordered by William Patterson University and private residential communities, so hikers should stay on established trails when visiting.

Sections of the trail are not well marked, so having the app accessible to help with navigation is helpful.

hits.name: Tower Hill and Jugtown Mountain Reserves
hits.description:
This hike takes you through two county parks - Tower Hill Reserve and Jugtown Mountain Reserve.  Tower Hill is fairly flat and open (though the fields are overgrown).  Jugtown Mountain is forested and has a steep section. It is also the site of an old mine and passes pits and tailing piles  The connector between the two is rocky and muddy with a couple of small stream crossing the path.
From the roadside parking lot in Tower Hill head up the road towards the intersection. At the intersection you will see the Park sign on the right - the trail starts behind the sign. Head into the woods and take the first left away from the road.  Follow the trail on the outside edge passing two intersecting trails and a power line cut (take in the view) until you come back to the road.  The trail takes you past the overgrown fields and a few small wooded sections.
At the road turn right and walk up to the Spring House looking for the trail on the left (note all the trails so far are unblazed, but well mown.) Take the trail into the field as it follows the edge of the field looking for the Highlands Trail teal blazes. Take the Highlands trail into the woods.  This is the connector section and is rocky and wet. At one point it crosses a grassy cut and is not well marked - walk to the left looking for the blazes in the woods.
Eventually the trail comes to Mine Road. Turn left and walk a short distance on the road to where the trail enters the woods into Jugtown Mountain Preserve.  In this first section, you will see the mine pits, tailing piles and old foundations before you come to a parking lot.  Enter the woods on the other side - the trail is joined by the White trail.  Take the trail as it heads down the side of the mountain.  At the bottom the Highlands trail meets Rt 173 and continues south - turn around here and climb back up hill.  When you come to the white trail intersection turn right and take the White trail back uphill to the parking lot (it will rejoin the Highlands trail at one point).
From the lot backtrack on the Highlands trail to Tower Hill.  When you come to intersection at the field, continue on the Highlands trail, which will take your right back to the start.

hits.name: Ledgewood/Morris Canal Park Yellow Trail
hits.description: Great hike with beautiful rock outcroppings. Steep ascent, then a pleasurable walk through mossy areas and boulders. Stream crossing; when the water is high, walk upstream a few yards for an easy spot to cross. Beautiful pond at start of hike with benches and a picnic table. Remnants of Morris Canal incline plane, tow path and water turbine along trail.

hits.name: Dogwood Trail
hits.description: Start from the parking lot (free, but closed Mondays and Sunday mornings) and head up the Dogwood spur, pass through a gate (make sure to close after you), and then head either clockwise or anti-clockwise around the loop. The Dogwood trail is marked by the New Jersey Audubon logo and occasionally red blazes. The trail leads through splendid forest and at one point shares its way with the locally famous Patriots Path trail.

hits.name: Stephens State Park Orange, White and Pots N Pans Loop
Cooper Union Loop
hits.description: This route is frequently used by mountain bikers so it's important to share the trail. The beginning of this trail can be quite rocky and leads up to an incredible view of the Ramapo Reservoir. This is a local favorite of those in the area! Dogs are allowed on the trails but they must be under voice control or on a leash.

hits.name: Pennington Park Trail
hits.description:
There are several paths to take and here at Pennington Park. The eastern section of this loop is paved while the remainder of the route is gravel or boardwalks.

Accessibility: There are 5 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Creek Road in the center of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, boardwalk (with edge barriers and partial railings), or gravel. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Pequannock Watershed: Hank's Pond
hits.description:
Hiking at Newark Watershed is by permit only. Please see here for details: https://www.newarknj.gov/card/hiking
Newark Residents: $8.00
Newark Seniors: $4.00
Non-Newark Residents: $14.00
Non-Newark Seniors: $8.00

hits.name: Woosamonsa Ridge White and Red Trail Loop
hits.description: Easy and scenic 2 mile loop. Small parking lot on Woosamonsa Rd.

hits.name: Steven's State Park Orange Loop
hits.description: Orange trail. Nice incline. Lots of salamanders.

hits.name: Delaware and Raritan Trail: Interstate 95 to Easton
Purple/White, Trailside Discovery and Lake Surprise Loop
Van Campens Glen Waterfalls from Northern Trailhead
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Maple Grange Loop
hits.description:
There are exercise stations along this route. Several places to stop and rest after hills.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lots off of Maple Grange Road in the center of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt or a natural (dirt and fallen leaf) surface. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest sections are from about 0.5 through 0.8 miles when going clockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the natural surface areas and grade. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Hawk Rise Sanctuary Loop Trail
Swamp Trail to North End Trail
Malaga Lake Nature Trail
hits.description: Walked the whole loop at sunset.

hits.name: Batsto River: Quaker Bridge to Batsto Village
Little Bear and Ridge Trails Loop
Willow Crest Loop Trail
hits.description:
Lake, Streams and Wetlands

This is a loop hike and starts at the parking lot.  Follow the blue blazed trail.  You will hike through open hardwood forest, along creaks and swamps.  You will also go past beautiful Willowcrest lake.  Great area for bird watching, because of the variety of habitates you will pass through.  Excellent for those looking to get out for an easy hike.  After your hike you can head down to Swartswood State Park and kayak the 500acre  Swartswood lake.

hits.name: Morris County High Point Via Ogden Mine Railroad Bed
hits.description: To access this trail you need to park at the Saffin Pond parking lot and cross Weldon Road to the Ogden Mine Ogden Mine Railroad bed trail. Take that trail to its end and make a right on Orange. Take Orange to its end and make a right on White. On White you'll pass Morris Counties Highest Point. White will eventually meet with Blue and an unmarked trail which starts witha marked biking trail marker. Take the unmarked trail across Weldon road until you meet with yellow. Be sure to check your All Trails GPS as there are other unmarked trails that intercept the trail you need to get back to the Saffin Pond lot. Once you link up to the Yellow Trail, you can take that back directly to the Saffin Pond lot.

hits.name: Batona and Quaker Bridge Trails: Carranza Memorial to Atsion
hits.description: This is the fourth section of the Batona trail. Start at Carranza Memorial and walk south for approximately 6 miles to Quaker Bridge.  From Quaker Bridge walk another 5 miles to Atsion Lake Visitor Center and the cars. You can take the purple Quaker Bridge trail to the yellow Mullica River trail and then follow that back to Atsion Lake. This is a beautiful section of the trail with lots of wild blueberries to snack on.

hits.name: Wallkill and Vernon Valleys via Appalachian Trail
Island Heights Loop
hits.description:
Waterfront and streets. As many hills on the streets as you want.

Accessibility: Please check with your law enforcement officials about which direction mobility equipment users are supposed to travel on roadways before proceeding. There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of River Avenue at the south end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, concrete, or boardwalk (with partial edge barriers and railings). 

It is typically 3 to 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less) and the steepest section is at about 0.2 miles when going counterclockwise. Trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper section or to avoid it for safety. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Corson Inlet Yellow
hits.description: Trailhead is adjacent to the parking lot. Follow marked trail to the Atlantic Ocean. Lots of ticks in spring.

hits.name: Green Village Trail Loop
hits.description: This is an official Chatham Township trail marked with a kiosk near the edge of Green Village Road. It was constructed and maintained by volunteers in the Chathams.

hits.name: Lizard Tail Swamp Yellow and Blue Loop
Darlington to New Jersey Botanical Gardens
Rahway River Perimeter Loop
hits.description:
1.1 mile paved loop around the park's recreational facilities including playgrounds and picnic areas.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spots in the parking lot in front of the pool, and an additional 6 across street. There are also several auxiliary parking areas with accessible parking throughout the park. The loop is wide and paved with minimal elevation gain, and there are several benches and picnic tables for resting.

hits.name: Teetertown to Crystal Springs Preserve
hits.description:
This route begins at Teetertown Ravine Nature Preserve and heads to Crystal Springs Preserve. 

Teetertown Preserve is heavily wooded while Crystal Springs is primarily comprised of fields (with five ponds). The connector trail between the two can be very muddy. 

From the parking lot, head down Old Orchard Trail (a gravel road) to the grass road heading towards the woods where you will find the start of the Blue Trail. Take the Blue Trail downhill to Teetertown Road. Turn left and then left again onto the unpaved Hollow Brook Road that parallels a stream in the Teetertown Ravine. Bypass the Geology Trail, but take the White blazed trail back up into the woods. The White ends at the Red Trail. Turn right and follow the Red as it winds along above the ravine (you can hear, but not see the stream). Take the left when the Red splits (the right goes back down to the road). Eventually the trail leads you into a mown field (the Activity field).

Leave the Red Trail and walk diagonally to your left across the field looking for the opening in the woods by two small sheds. Walk the gravel road through the woods and the campgrounds until it comes out to a parking lot. Walk to the road, find the white striped path across Pleasant Grove Rd, and enter into the woods directly on the other side. You are now in Crystal Springs. Follow the Orange trail through the muddy woods until you come out on a large field. 

Walk along the edge of the field to the left all the way to the other side of the field (you will see the springs/ponds on the other side). Walk until you see a gravel road leaving the field. Follow this to a T intersection (diverge a bit to check out the pond on the gravel path). 

At the T intersection, turn left and walk the road. The road ends at a second pond, but before the pond, there is a narrow path to the right heading uphill through some woods to a small field. At the field, turn left and walk a short distance to another break in the trees to a larger field on the left. At that field, turn right and walk along the edge to the first corner - walk through the trees to a bigger field. At this point you can turn right and start back, or walk a short distance to the left to the beginning of the Red trail, which goes for a 1/4 mile before dead ending (at some point this trail will go to Point Mountain). 

Back at the field, head to the right and walk along the edge of the field to the next even bigger field continuing northeast until you get to the Crystal Springs parking lot. From the lot take the gravel road back past two other ponds until you come to that T intersection. Turn right and head back to the field. Follow the field edge to the left until you find the entrance to the Orange trail in the woods (near a corner of the field). 

Take the Orange back to Teetertown's lot. At the lot turn right, go through the campground, and past a pond following Pond Road back to the starting point.

hits.name: Watershed Trail
hits.description:
Visitors have reported that this route is poorly marked and sometimes the markers go in the opposite direction so you may want to bring the app or download the map beforehand.

Journey through a diversity of habitats on this moderately challenging trail from the Watershed Center to the northernmost point on the Watershed Reserve. Traverse meadow, pond, stream, deciduous and coniferous forest, and view a large stand of conifers blown by Super Storm Sandy. The northern reach of the trail ascends 150 feet up the boulder strewn Mount Rose Ridge before descending into the Bedens Brook Watershed near Hopewell Borough.

hits.name: Liberty State Park, Caven Point, Port Liberty
hits.description: Along the Hudson River Walkway from Liberty State Park to Port Liberte with a stop at the beach at Caven Point. The Caven Point trail is closed between April and October. Dogs on leash allowed.

hits.name: White Trail, Blue Trail, and Purple/Yellow Trail Loop
Cooper River and Maria Barnaby Greenwald Trail Loop
Berkshire Valley Management Area Trail
hits.area_name: Berkshire Valley State Wildlife Management Area
hits.description:
This trail follows the Right-of-Way of the former Central Railroad of New Jersey's Lake Hopatcong Railroad from Gordon Road in Wharton, NJ to Minisink Road in Jefferson, NJ. The route was once heavily used to access iron mines and to bring seasonal vacationers from Jersey City to Nolan's Point on Lake Hopatcong.

It's a straightforward but rocky path running along the eastern edge of the Berkshire Valley State Wildlife Management Area. The path encounters a few small streams on its 2.5 mile run and there are even a few remains of the old railroad if you look hard enough for them.

hits.name: Garrett Family Preserve Trail
hits.area_name: Garrett Family Preserve at Cape Island Creek

hits.name: D & L Trail: Uhlerstown to Hendrick Island
hits.description: The Deleware River Canal State Park from Uhlerstown to Lumberville has the smooth, even surface common to the entire canal towpath. The best scenery along this section is the Delaware River itself. Should you want to make a loop of the trip, cross the pedestrian only bridge at Lumberville over Bulls Island and join the Delaware and Ruritan Canal North to Frenchtown. After crossing the bridge continue south on Rt. 32 a short way and turn left just before the covered bridge. This will take you back to Tinicum Park for a loop of almost 17 miles.

hits.name: Echo Lake West Trail
hits.description:
Easy hike along the shore of Echo Lake with nice views

A permit is required for this hike and all hikes on NWCDC property. It can be purchased at the office at 220 Echo Lake Rd (the starting point for this hike).

Catch the Highlands Trail (blue diamond blazes) at the SW corner of the parking lot and go towards the lake. It soon joins the white blazed Echo Lake West Trail and together they follow the shore line, with several nice views along the way. At about the 1.5 mile point the Highlands Trail leaves to the left. Continue following white blazes to the trails end at an outstanding overlook at the north end of the lake. Retrace your route to your car.

Optionally, if you don't mind a short road walk, you can continue past the trails end on an unmarked, but well defined trail. Follow to brook and  come out on Gould Rd. Turn right and catch the Echo Lake East Trail (white blazes)  on right just past Sherwood Ct. Highlands Trail soon joins from left. Follow Highlands trail back to car

This trail is closed Sundays and holidays.

hits.name: Read Ave, Peace, and Old Hilltop Trail Loop
hits.description: This trail is a great place to bring kids for a quiet walk in the woods.

hits.name: Fort Lee Historic Park Trails
hits.description:
This is a historic pathway through the Revolutionary War with beautiful views of NYC and the George Washington Bridge.

Accessibility: There is 1 designated accessible space in the paved parking lot off of Hudson Terrace at the north end of the trail. It is van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

hits.name: Turtle Back Rock Interpretive Trail
hits.description: This is a close to one-mile interpretive loop beginning at Turtle Back Rock Rd. It is blazed with white and orange. The trail features a massive rock covered in a turtle shell like pattern that gives the trail its name.

hits.name: North Hudson Loop
hits.description:
This is a paved path around a lake in North Hudson Park. There is a nice view of New York City and plenty of wildlife. There is also a cafe, basketball courts, splash pad, and tennis courts. 

Accessibility: There are 3 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of John F. Kennedy Boulevard East at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved concrete, smooth, and typically at least 6 feet wide. The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Pinwheel Vista via Appalachian Trail
hits.description:
Take the Appalachian Trail from Warwick Turnpike up and over a series of hills to Pinwheel Vista (top of Stairway to Heaven).

From the top, there are incredible views of the surrounding farmlands and mountains.

About half a mile from the trailhead is the Wawayanda Shelter available for camping. During the late spring and early summer months is it highly trafficked by Appalachian Trail thru-hikers.

hits.name: Orchard, Summit, and Spring Trail Loop
Lower Forge to Batona Trail to Goodwater Road Loop
Sussex Branch Trail: Lafayette - Newton
hits.description: This is a section of the Sussex Branch Trail.  This section goes between Lafayette and Newton.  There is a small parking area  off of Rt 94 to start/end.

hits.name: Watchung Reservation White Trail
hits.description:
Park in the lot for the strip mall at the bottom of the hill on rt 22 and walk on meadow street to donato. There is a trail entrance to the right, clearly marked with signs just before you enter the apartment complex.

Walk up a short incline and the trail intersects with the white blaze trail. Make a slight right to continue up the Watchung ridge. There are a few overlooks of the rock quarry after a steep incline. 

Continue on the white trail to Glenside Ave. (Optional side trail to the left will take you to a picnic area. Trail intersects with Glenside ave just after this). make a left here and walk a short distance before crossing Sky Top road. The re-entry point for the white trail is directly across the street and marked with a sign. 

Continue until you cross green brook on a wooden bridge. If you want to check out the abandoned village of feltville follow the trail slightly to the left which heads directly up a steep incline . The ruins and trail are easily visible from the bridge. 

From here you can extend the hike by continuing on the white or purple and yellow trails, or turn back. The white trail splits just after the bridge. You can go right to return the same way or to the left for a steeper incline. The two segments of white trail converge again after 0.3 miles and you backtrack your steps to the parking lot from here.

You can hear the traffic for most of the hike due to its close proximity to roads but it is a convenient hike if you live nearby.

hits.name: Washington Valley Orange Trail and East Branch Middle Brook trail
Pond and Nature Loop
Tamaques Park Loop
hits.description:
This is a popular local park for running, cycling, and walking.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Lambert Mill Road at the west end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt and smooth. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. 

The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Baldwin Lake via Pennington Loop Nature Trail
Stony Brook Trails: Greenway Meadows to Princeton Battlefield
hits.description: This route combines a nature trail along the Stony Brook with a paved path through a residential area, starting at Princeton Greenway Meadows park and ending at Princeton Battlefield State Park. For a shorter route, turn back at U.S. 206.

hits.name: Andover Township Rail Trail
hits.description:
Out and back on the rail trail between Lake Iliff Road and Mulford Road. The trail is mostly flat.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Lake Iliff Road at the southwest end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is packed gravel, and typically 3 to over 6 feet wide. 

The estimated grade is gentle (all 3% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surface type. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Parker Loop High Point Trail
hits.description:
This loop takes you through some great forest of Hemlocks, Beach, Oak, Sugar, Red Maples, and Birch trees. Along the Howell, Cartwright, and Criss trails you go along many creeks. Like the Flatbrook, Criss, Forked and Parker Brooks, making for a very scenic hike, especially with the Foliage. You will also cross over a wild Trout Stream, the Parker Brook. Along the loop you come to one great viewpoint overlooking Stokes, High Point and the Poconos. Down in the Valleys you also come to old stone foundations from farms that once worked the land.  

There is a dried-up well along the Cartwright Trail and many springs along the Howell trail.  Along the Flatbrook there is an old foundation from a Grist Mill.

hits.name: Bunker Hill Natural Area Brown Trail to Yellow Trail
Bonnabel Nature Path
hits.description: This is a nice trail that meanders through the woods next to a gentle stream.

hits.name: Lenape Trail and Grassy Trail Loop
Gnome Hollow Preserve Yellow Trail
hits.description:
This is a loop (the middle section overlaps a bit the way the trail is blazed) in the Gnome Hollow Preserve.

In this section, there is a connecting Orange trail that takes you to the neighboring Frelinghusen Forest Preserve.

The section of the trail near the  parking area, closest Stillwater Road was not quite as well blazed nor is there as well defined 'beaten path'.

hits.name: Pryde's Point-Alexauken Creek
hits.description: This route in a shady park is well marked and studded with rock stairs, rock crossings and features a creek small tributaries and small gullies. The water flows here even in dry periods. In rainy weather, the trail might be muddy. While most of the park is shady though access from either parking spot requires crossing open fields. An early 20th century abandoned house should not be mistaken for the revolutionary war storage shed further up on the orange trail. The trail is good for all skill levels and best used in the spring and summer months.

hits.name: Overlook Rock Trail
hits.description:
Short hike over varied terrain to an outstanding overlook. Eventually this will connect with another trail that is being planned and a nice loop hike can be made. For now it's out and back, with the option of returning via some of the woods roads that lace the area.  

Starting at the trailhead, climb to the ridge and continue along the ridgeline. The trail soon descends into a ravine, then climbs another ridge with a decent westerly view just off the trail. It then descends steeply on switchbacks, crosses a brook and eventually reaches the shore of Lake Sonoma, where a few nice views of the lake can be found. 

From here it climbs to Overlook Rock where there is an outstanding 180 degree easterly view. Return the way you came, or optionally take one of the woods roads back to your car.

hits.name: Franklin Parker Green Trail
hits.description: Franklin Parker Preserve - Green Trail

hits.name: Veterans Park Blue, Red and Yellow Trail Loop
hits.description: Parking: 40 Conkling Road in Ledgewood for the blue and red trails. The blue trail is mostly an unpaved easement road with slight hills.  Suitable for walking and biking at most levels of ability.  Look for start of the newly renovated red trail about a 1/4 of a mile in, on the left side. This trail explores the eastern side of Mooney Mountain. It creates a loop connecting the blue and yellow trails, and is more technical as it winds its way through woodlands and rocky terrain. This trail brings you through large rock outcroppings (that look like giant sleeping turtles) and a stone structure. When the red trail ends, turn right onto yellow trail. At end, turn right onto blue trail. Look for two dirt bikes about 25’ up in the trees, on the left side of the trail. Veterans Park offers 240 acres of wooded land containing four marked hiking trails, which require different levels of ability.

hits.name: Tranquility Trails, High Hill Park, and Locke Ave Park Loop
hits.description:
This trail follows the perimeter of several former farm fields that are now wildflower meadows and are linked by trails that go through woods and wetlands to create the loop shown here. Portions of the trail offers glimpses of Raccoon Creek.   

Earlier in 2020, Woolwich Township installed a ten foot wide, paved multi use trail along High Hill Road that connects Tranquility Trail with High Hill West Park and Locke Avenue Park.  Together, these tracts are part of 420 acres of contiguous land that will continue to be developed into different passive and active uses for public use over the next several years.  

By connecting these 3 parks, you can create a longer loop. The hike begins at the Tranquility Trails with a loop along mowed grass trails.  The next 0.5 miles is on the paved connector trail.  As you enter High Hill West park, there is an option to follow a 0.3 mile trail that bisects the park, or you can choose to walk counter-clockwise along the maintained perimeter of the park for about 0.5 miles before rejoining the paved trail to cross a bridge into Locke Avenue Park.

After a little over a mile on 8 ft wide paved trails that go between various athletic fields, walk about 1 mile along the perimeter of the undeveloped Northern portion of the park.  Be aware that the road in this area of the park is only mowed sporadically so you may want to shorten this portion of the hike to about 0.5 miles if you follow the regularly maintained areas.  If you do follow the road, however, you are rewarded with additional views of Raccoon Creek.  The hike then goes back through High Hill West and the paved connector trail back to the Tranquility Trails parking lot.  

This is a relatively flat and level hike. There is additional parking available along this loop in High Hill West Park or Locke Avenue Park.  Permanent restroom facilities are available in both High Hill West Park and Locke Avenue Park along with several porta-potties.  Water is available in non-winter months at Locke Avenue Park.

hits.name: Lincoln Park Loop
hits.description:
This path is wholly within Lincoln Park in Jersey City and has lots of lovely features. This is a great trail for those sporting strollers, kids, or puppers!

Accessibility: There are at least 6 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Duncan Avenue in the center of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is pavement, gravel, or natural (grass/dirt) and typically at least 5 feet wide. There is a painted dividing line along some of the trail which reduces the width.

The estimated grade is mostly gentle (5% or less) except for a moderately steep (5-8%) uphill and downhill section from about 5.4 through 6.0 miles in the southeast portion of the route. Trail goers/hikers using wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers may need assistance in the steeper sections and areas without curb-cuts or to avoid them for safety. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved areas. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Glen Trail
hits.description: This short, peaceful trail can be easily connected to other area trails for a much longer route.

hits.name: Schooley's Mountain Park: Orange and Yellow Loop
Cherry Ridge Trail
hits.description:
A pleasant, easy hike with some nice scenery. A pleasant, shorter verison of the Wawayanda Jungle Trail. A great place for cross country skiing in season.

Take Cherry Ridge Rd west from the parking area. It's an unpaved woods road here. After about .5 miles, make a right onto the Red Dot trail (actually blazed by red squares). The trail is flat but passes some interesting terrain. It eventually crosses a stone bridge and reaches Double Pond Road. There is an interesting swamp at this junction and a boardwalk that makes for a good spot to stop for lunch. Continue southeast on the yellow blazed Double Pond trail and after a short distance make a right onto the blue blazed Cedar Swamp Trail. This trail goes through a swamp on boards and then through interesting rhododendron tunnels. It eventually reaches the yellow blazed Banker Trail. Make a right here and take it back to the parking area.

hits.name: Beach Glen Trail
hits.area_name: Wildcat Ridge State Wildlife Management Area
hits.description: Hiking trail next to Wildcat Ridge Management Trail. It’s a blue mark trail. One mark and it loops back before changing to a new trail name.

hits.name: Schiff Nature Preserve Blue and Red Trail
Cold Spring Bike Path
hits.description:
This paved trail heads from Cold Spring to Rio Grande. It goes by the Historic Cold Spring Village and crosses two intersections with crosswalks. 

Accessibility: There are not any designated accessible spaces at the south end of the trail at Sandman Boulevard and Seashore Road. There are at least 2 designated accessible spaces at about 0.9 miles at the Historic Cold Spring Village. It is unclear if they are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. This partially paved parking lot is marked with a waypoint. 

The trail surface is smooth asphalt or cement, and typically at least 6 feet wide. There is a painted center lane line along most of the trail which reduces the width. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most trail goers with wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

hits.name: Randolph Trails (Old Brookside Road and Heistein Park) and Patriots Path
hits.description: 6.2 mile out and back hike on sections of the Patriots Path and Randolph Trails (blue/white trail) between Old Brookside Road and Heistein Park with a stop at Heistein pond. This is an easy, well marked trail with connections and extensions to continue exploring.

hits.name: Spring Lake Park Loop
hits.description:
Good loop for running and walking. The path is wide enough to pass other pedestrians too. If you want to go off trail, there are many pull-offs that go into town or to different streets.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Maple Avenue by the north end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved asphalt or concrete. It is typically 4 to 6 feet wide. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There is a wheelchair-accessible bathroom by the north end of the trail.

hits.name: Buttermilk Falls and Rattlesnake Mountain Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Washington Rock Nature Trail
hits.description: A nice mix of trail and pavement walking with an amazing view from Washington Rock.

hits.name: Allamuchy Red to Blue Loop
hits.description: Starts flat along Jeff Lake and then make a left on to Red trail.  Take fork to blue trail for additional elevation.  You cannot see Cranberry Lake from the top. Hike down was moderate.  Passed some old mining ruins.  Nice small stream and waterfall along the way back down.

hits.name: Morristown Blue, Grand Loop and Yellow Trail
Great Falls Lake, Otter Lake, Dukes Brook Loop
hits.description:
A beautiful walk at Duke Farms!
A pet cemetery, the old foundation, the lakes and a perfect season to see the leafless tree architecture!

hits.name: Beckett Park Loop
hits.description:
Beckett Loop utilizes walking trails, nature trails and parks to create a 3.2 mile loop that connects the different neighborhoods in Beckett.  The loop begins and ends at a large parking lot at Beckett Park located just off Township Line Road in Logan Township.  Virtually the entire walk is on paved sidewalks or walking trails that are 4-5 ft wide. Some sections do not have sidewalk and require walking in a neighborhood street.  No major streets have to be crossed.

Accessibility: There are 7 designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Township Line Road at the southwest end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved (asphalt, cement, and wooden bridge with railings) and typically at least 4 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most users with wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers. There are benches along the route for resting.

hits.name: Jonathan's Woods White, Red, Blue, Green, Yellow, and Purple Trail Loop
hits.description:
Jonathan's Woods is a 500+ acre property maintained by the Morris County Parks Commission. 

The sections of the route following the Purple trail will be the best for birding opportunities. 

The area is open for bowhunting seasonally, so hikers are reminded to stay on blazed trails and wear bright colors.

hits.name: Cranberry Overlook Trail
hits.description:
There is a mini-loop you can take either on the way to or the way back from the overlook.

The trail is short and pretty steep, but you get a very nice view of Cranberry Lake when you get to the top.

hits.name: Lenape Trail: Branch Brook Park to South Mountain Reservation
hits.description: This is an approximation of the Lenape Trail, beginning in Branch Brook Park and ending at South Mountain Reservation

hits.name: Banker Trail, Double Pond Trail, Sitting Bear Trail, and Cherry Ridge Road Loop
Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge Orange and Red Loop Trails
Beaver Pond- Quaker Bridge Trail to Lower Forge Campground
hits.description: This trail connects the Mullica River Trail with the Batona Trail, and also provides access to the Lower Forge Wilderness Camp.

hits.name: Lawrence Hopewell Trail: Carson Road Woods Segment
hits.description:
The Lawrence Hopewell Trail (LHT) is a 20+ miles bicycle and pedestrian recreational trail and transportation corridor in Lawrence and Hopewell Townships, Mercer County, New Jersey. This segment is in Carson Road Woods, which is historic farmland preserved by Lawrence Township, NJ. This segment is one of the oldest segments of the trail and bridges most of the distance between corporate campuses of two of the trail's largest benefactors: Bristol Myers Squibb and Educational Testing Service (ETS).

Accessibility: There are no designated accessible spaces in the gravel parking lot off of Carson Road at the south end of the trail. There do not appear to be any designated accessible parking spaces within 1.0 miles of the trailhead. The trail surface is gravel or a natural surface (dirt, rocks). It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the gentle (3% or less) grade category. All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the surface type.

hits.name: Ramsey Rail Trail
hits.description:
This route heads between Prospect Street and the Interstate Shopping Center at Addison Place. There are several road crossings along the way.

Accessibility: There are several designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Addison Place at the north end of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved. It is typically 3 to 6 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces). There are metal bollards at street crossings along the trail which reduces the width temporarily. 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the gentle grade category (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Batona Trail: Rt 563 to Bass River (Southern Trailhead)
Laurelwood Arboretum Trails
hits.description: Take a nice and quiet walk through the beautiful variety of wildlife and plant species that are abundant at the Laurelwood Arboretum. There is no entrance fee but donations are always welcomed at the visitor center. Friends of Laurelwood Arboretum will offer tours sometimes, and you can check their website for more details.

hits.name: Roxbury Black River Trail
hits.description: Park at 1 Main Street, Succasunna, NJ. The scenic trail on the property is level and suitable for walking for all ages.  The gold-marked path within the park is approximately one mile out and back, and has a small loop, marked with blue blazes.  Most of the trail is along the Black River, and has some dips and roots to cross. Things to look for:  a beautiful line of cedar trees, which shaded horses in their past, and two bridges to cross a stream.  There’s a small hill, which used to be a ski hill.  A pair of swans are often seen in Black River Pond, as well as turtles. The far end of the trail connects with trails leading to Mine Hill and Randolph.

hits.name: Sussex Branch Trail: Newton to Branchville
hits.description: Sussex Branch Trail from Newton to Branchville

hits.name: Long Bridge Park Red Trail
hits.description:
This route features a short boardwalk. There are reservable pavilions along with restrooms and playgrounds. 

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Mount Holly Bypass in the center of the trail. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is a wooden boardwalk (with railings), gravel, or a natural (dirt and grass) surface. It is typically at least4 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting. There are wheelchair-accessible picnic tables and wheelchair-accessible bathrooms here.

hits.name: Reed’s Basket Willow Swamp
hits.description: Great little trail. What it lacks in distance it makes up for with some nice hill climbs and serene surroundings.

hits.name: Lusscroft Tour Route
hits.description: Hike through old sugar maple forests, across streams, along ponds and fields and to the top of the Kittatinny Ridge. Catch a glimpse of the historic Lusscroft Farm. The Lusscroft Tour hike starts at the gate.

hits.name: Village Park to Twin Pines Park
hits.description: This is an easy hike between Village Park in Lawrence Township and Twin Pines Park, jointly owned by Lawrence and Hopewell Township, via Mercer Meadows County Park. Village Park has athletic fields and playground facilities. Twin Pines Park mainly just has athletic fields. Mercer Meadows is a nature preserve consisting of a restored grassland on the site of the former AT&T oversees transmission facility (a historic site).

hits.name: Snuffy Hollow Trail and Pitch Pine Loop
Unblazed and White to Buell Trail (Orange) Long Loop
Curlis Woods - Mercer County Equestrian Center to Pennington
hits.description: This trail is a part of the equestrian district of Mercer Meadows County Park. This particular trail is an out and back trail, starting at a junction with the Lawrence Hopewell Trail at the Mercer County Equestrian Center and ending at Main Street in Pennington.

hits.name: Forge Pond - Metedeconk River Kayak Trail
Foote’s Pond Loop
hits.description:
This is a beautiful pond with water fowl and turtles in this half mile loop around a pond. The wetlands are preserved nicely by locals. It is a great walk on a level gravel surface.

Accessibility: It is unclear if there are any designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Overlook Road at the northwest end of the trail. The trail surface is gravel or wooden bridge with railings. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. The whole trail is estimated to be in the flat (1% or less) grade category. This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or stroller users.

hits.name: Monksville Mines and Sterling Forest Loop
Darlington Park Trail
hits.description:
A large section of this trail is a maintenance road. Trail goers may be relegated to a narrow path when vehicles are present. If sharing the roadway with motor vehicles, using reflector strips, mounted lights, or bright flags is recommended for safety.

Accessibility: Please check with your local law enforcement officials about which direction mobility equipment users are supposed to travel on roadways before proceeding. 

It is unclear if there are designated accessible spaces in the large paved parking lot off of Darlington Avenue at the north end of the trail. The trail surface is paved asphalt or gravel. It is typically at least 5 feet wide (with many wider passing spaces). 

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the unpaved surfaces. There are benches and picnic tables along the route for resting.

hits.name: Gatun Pond via Crossover and Old White Trail
hits.description: This trail begins from the NJ Arboretum in Ringwood, NJ in the parking lot C.

hits.name: Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge Blue, Yellow, and Ivory Trails
hits.description:
The Blue, Yellow and Ivory trails are in the Wilderness Area of the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge.

The "wilderness" designation means that this area offers many wildlife observation, birding, and photography opportunities. In addition, this is a protected area for wildlife. Dog walking and biking are strictly prohibited. Bridges, boardwalks, and power equipment are allowed in very limited situations so deep mud, large fallen trees and flooded trails are common for long periods of time. Hikers should wear knee high rubber boots, stay on the trail, and avoid widening the trails by skirting the mud spots.

hits.name: Tenafly Nature Center Yellow, Red, and White Loop
Clinton Reservoir From Dead Man's Curve
hits.description:
Hiking at Newark Watershed is by permit only. Please see here for details: https://www.newarknj.gov/card/hiking
Newark Residents: $8.00
Newark Seniors: $4.00
Non-Newark Residents: $14.00
Non-Newark Seniors: $8.00

hits.name: Allamuchy Pond Trail
hits.description: If you'd like to extend your hike, you can continue on from this route to a connector trail, and then to Deer Path Trail.

hits.name: Silver Lake and Mud Pond Loop Trail
