Great Valley Trail: Paulins Kill to Augusta
hits.description: The Great Valley Trail is fairly wide in most sections and there are a few muddy sections that you have to skirt around some large puddles.

hits.name: Peace, Spruce Outer, Spruce Inner, and Old Hilltop Trail Loop
hits.description: This loop takes users through a quiet wooded area, some might forget they're in such a busy urban area.

hits.name: Lusscroft Farm Loop
hits.description:
The Lusscroft farm has a long history in NJ farming.  It was the first place where artificial Insemination occurred in cows.  The farm was also set up as an experimental farm.  The Lusscroft farm lies in the kittatinny Mountains. The views from the farm are awesome with the High Lands in the distance and the Kittatinny valley below.  It is also the headwaters of the Papakating Creek.  The steep escarpment along Neilson Rd is made up of Volcanic rock.  

The actually volcano is the hill just before the farm.  It is called Rutan Hill. For more info go to the site listed.  The hike itself takes you through Stokes SF and High Point SP.  You will pass a plane wreck, Pete Bog and see some old mines.  This hike is not recommended for the beginner.  You need to be able to use map and compass and have a good sense of direction since this hike takes you on unmarked trail and woods roads.

hits.name: Corson Inlet Red
hits.description: Trail parallels the beach to the west of the first set of dunes. It branches off the the Yellow Trail which is accessed from the parking lot. Lots of ticks in June.

hits.name: Paulinskill Valley Trail - Hardwick to Frelinghuysen
hits.description:
4.5 miles out and back on the Paulinskill Valley trail.  This section is in Hardwick and Frelinghuysen townships.  There is a small parking lot on the Hardwick end on Spring Valley Road.

There are some soft/muddy spots and the trail is definitely used a lot by horses so watch where you are walking.

hits.name: Holly Grove
hits.description: This is a short, beautiful trail along a ridge line.

hits.name: Frelinghuysen Forest North Yellow Loop
hits.description: This route follows a combination of the yellow and blue blazed trails.

hits.name: Pequest Wildlife Management Area Trails
hits.description: This route is a combination of the red, yellow, and blue marked trails.

hits.name: Lenape Trail to Eifall
hits.description: Short out and back access to the West Essex Rail Trail.  Good diversity for a short hike that can be combined with other trails in the area.

hits.name: Appalachian, Swenson, and Tower Trail Loop
hits.description:
The hike starts with a steep climb to get warmed up, then levels off and follows the ridge. Lots of nice views, and not just from the fire tower and pavilion! After the leaves have fallen the views are wonderful along the entire ridgeline. 

Shortly after the Sunrise Mountain parking lot, turn left onto the light blue trail. When the blue trail forks, turn left. Follow it all the way back to the green and brown trails. Take the green back up the hill to join up with the AT at the fire tower This is a nice climb to end the hike with some more views.

The park also has printed copies of the map available.

hits.name: Bunker Loop
hits.description:
This is a short, paved, wide woodland trail leading to an old bunker site. Abundant holly and laurel line the path.

As most of this trail has an estimated grade over 8%, it is not marked as wheelchair or stroller friendly, although some parts of it may be for some users or all-terrain/motorized equipment. There are 2 designated handicapped-accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off Portland Road at the trailhead. Both of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles.

hits.name: Bonnabel Nature Park Short Loop
hits.description:
A flat trail through the woods alongside the Hackensack River.

A great trail for pets and kids!

hits.name: Cactus Island Main Trail and Island Trail Loop
hits.description:
This loop begins on the main trail and then turns onto the Island Trail which is marked with blue blazes.

Along the trail, visitors will walk past the farmhouse site and osprey nesting platforms.

hits.name: HIghlands Trail (NJ3): Route 181 to Route 206
hits.description: Hike the non-roadway sections of HT (NJ3) in four separate out and back segments. Parking can be found at the waypoints included (Byram Intermediate School (Mansfield Drive), Route 605, and at the Mountain Inlet connector on Lakeside Ave).  Make sure to follow the blazes  as there are a few sections where the trail goes through private property and its imperative to stay on the trail to not trespass. In a few spots there are some 'beaten path' trails that are NOT the Highland Trail, so keep your head up and follow the blazes.

hits.name: Jersey Central Lines: Springer Brook to Deep Run
hits.description: Walk to the Springer Brook RR Trestle along the abandoned RR bed to the Deep Run RR Bridge and then along the lower Deep Run bog and back.

hits.name: Stone Harbor Point
hits.description: This route goes from Stone Harbor Beach to the inlet.

hits.name: Negri-Nepote Native Grassland Loop
hits.description: This is an easy trail running mostly through fields and grasslands with small sections in the woods. There are opportunities for birdwatching and glimpses of wildflowers.

hits.name: Lake Oswego
hits.description: Kayaked to the Papoose Branch and back down to Lake Oswego.

hits.name: Dorbrook Park East Loop
hits.description:
This is a nice paved trail with spots to veer off onto dirt paths through the trees to get closer to the water.

Accessibility: There are 4 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Monmouth Country Road at the southwest end of the trail near the basketball courts. All of them are van-accessible with striped access aisles. The trail surface is paved asphalt, smooth, and typically at least 10 feet wide. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). This trail will likely be navigable for most wheelchairs/mobility equipment or strollers.

hits.name: Highlands Trail (NJ 6): Schooley's Mountain Park to Voorhees State Park
hits.description:
This section of the Highlands Trail can be done as several out-and-backs. The section of the trail runs from Schooley's Mountain Park to Voorhees State Park. Note, there is a section of road walking along rt 513 near the end section before it reaches Voorhees State Park.

Parking can be centrally found at a few central locations. Please see waypoints along the route for the parking spots that are applicable. 
Parking
-along Fairview Ave
-intersection of the trail and Rt 517, 
-trail crossing at 513 midway
-trail intersection at W Valley Brook Rd
-Califon near the intersection of the trail with Rt 512, 
-a 4x4-friendly woods road lot near rt 513 on the Voorhees State Park end

hits.name: Brightwood Park Loop
hits.description: Family-friendly woodlands loop around a scenic lake. There are also a few benches for picnicking / relaxing.

hits.name: Round Mountain Section to River (Red) Trail Loop
hits.description:
This loop starts at Bouman Stickney Farm and crosses Round Mountain, Deer Path Park, the South Branch River Reservation and passes the Woods Church Farmstead.

Head south from Bouman Stickney on the Orange trail which will meet the White in a field.  Take the White South until you come to Stanton road. Turn right on the road and walk a short distance until you see the White trail enter the woods. Follow the White trail until you come to a Orange trail (Buell trail). Head south on the Orange trail, making sure you stay on the Orange at the intersections. The Orange trail will parallel the White and/or Yellow at times. 

The Orange trail will come to a three way intersection (one of the loops), take either and head south looking for another three way intersection at the bottom of the loop. Leave the loop and head south for a short distance to another three way intersection. Take the Orange trail going to the left which will eventually take you to a gate on Woodschurch Rd. Cross the Road and enter the maintained section of Deer Path park; head to the right along the road following the mowed trail.  You will eventually come to a fork where the Fitness trail goes off to the left; continue to the right until you see the road (Deerpath road).  

Walk down the road to the left and around the curve to the right until you come to the parking lot and the South Branch River Reservation.  Walk into the woods on the Red trail until you come to the River then turn left and follow the trail along the River until you come to an intersection where a Red trail heads away from the river.  Follow this back to Deer Path park and the picnic area.  Walk straight ahead with the restrooms on your right where you will pick up the Fitness trail again.  Continue on the Fitness trail until you see the gate across the street.  Cross the street and backtrack to the start of the hike.  (To make the return different take the other side of the loops on the way back).

hits.name: Rattlesnake Swamp, Coppermine, and Appalachian Trail Loop
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
hits.description:
Along the way have lunch on the cliff rocks near the fire tower. The Best views of the whole loop are there. 

Take a dip in Catfish Pond on the way by!

hits.name: Walpack Ridge Loop
hits.description: The trail is clear and well marked.  A few hills but not substantial.  On the way back it is worth continuing on past the access road to see the 1812 stone house.

hits.name: Merrill Park Loop
hits.description:
This suburban park features sports fields and a playground. There is also a nearby animal sanctuary.

Accessibility: The northeast lot has 2 striped van-accessible designated accessible parking spots. Other lots along the path offer additional accessible parking spots. The trail is wide, paved, and gentle, and there are benches throughout the trail for sitting and resting.

hits.name: Monmouth Junction Freedom Trail
hits.description:
This route is paved between Ridge Road and Stouts Lane but unpaved from Stouts to Route 1.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the small paved parking lot off of Ridge Road at the east end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a shared striped access aisle. 

The trail surface is a paved or natural (dirt/grass) surface. It is typically at least 6 feet wide. There are painted lane lines from Ridge Road to Stouts Lane which reduce the width. From Stouts Lane west to Route 1 the trail appears to be an unpaved double track that may create a steep (over 2%) cross slope with grass growing in the middle of the trail. 

The most accessible portion of the trail is the first 1.5 miles west which is smoothly paved. The estimated grade is gentle (3% or less). All-terrain tires and motorized equipment may be needed for the natural surface section past the 1.5-mile mark.

hits.name: Patriot's Path: Chester to Naughright
hits.description: Portions of this route come close to private property, so please stay on the trail and be respectful.

hits.name: Washington Valley Yellow Loop
hits.description: Down hill, switch backs, rock gardens, difficult rock climbs.  Some flow trails.

hits.name: Cains Mill Road Loop
hits.description:
The dirt portion of Cains Mill Road is difficult to drive in a 2WD vehicle.

There is no swimming allowed in the pond.

hits.name: Ringwood State Park Cupsaw Brook Loop
hits.description: Catch red on white blazed Ringwood Ramapo trail, cross bridge over stream then cross Sloatsburg Road. Climb a fairly steep section then bear left onto the yellow blazed Cooper Union Trail. Take this downhill until it meets the blue blazed Cupsaw Brook Trail turn right onto it.  Follow the blue blazes up hill, then down and along an old woods road. It soon joins the red blazed Ringwood Ramapo and follows a stream and crosses a swamp. Just after the swamp and a stream crossing the Ringwood Ramapo splits off to the right. Follow it back to your car.

hits.name: Cannonball, R/Y, Red, Old Guard and Schuber
Batona Trail: Carranza Memorial to Batsto Road
Lizard Tail Swamp Yellow Loop Trail
Orange Switchback Loop
hits.description: A 2.3 mile loop on the Allamuch Mountain State Park Switchback Loop Trail.  It's blazed as the Orange trail in the park, and it's essentially one long switchback.

hits.name: Paulinskill Valley and Sussex Branch Marsh Trail Loop
hits.description: Loads of birds including blue heron, and plenty of wineberries to snack on along the way!

hits.name: Orchard Trail
hits.area_name: Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

hits.name: Railroad Avenue: Atsion Furnace to Beaver Dam
hits.description:
From Atsion Furnace on Railroad Avenue and alongside the Mullica River to the Beaver Dam and back.

This is also an off-road driving area. If you're on foot, please be alert for passing vehicles.

hits.name: Old Orchard Trails Loop
hits.description:
An almost mile-long loop behind the school. Some areas may be narrow.

Accessibility: There are 2 designated accessible spaces in the paved parking lot off of Cropwell Road at the south end of the trail. Both of them are van-accessible with a striped access aisle. The trail surface is paved or a natural (dirt, grass, and root) surface. It is typically at least 3 feet wide (with some wider passing spaces).

The majority of the trail is estimated to be in the mostly gentle grade category (5% or less). All-terrain tires or motorized equipment may be needed for the mostly unpaved surface type.

hits.name: Cannonball and White Loop from Back Beach Park
hits.description: This route predominately explores trails within the Ramapo Mountain State Forest, but begins in Back Beach Park.

hits.name: Woods Walk North and South Loop via Inspiration Point Trail
